description.text:
I replaced an 110° and 3.8 mm distortion free lens for my sj4000, and now it's not match the waterproof case! Time to install an UV filter.

  1. Print both parts.
  2. Clear fluff, carefully.
  3. Clear threads, be sure two parts could be screwed smoothly.
  4. Screw a 37 mm UV filter onto the adapter, be sure it could be screwed smoothly.
  5. Clear them again.
  6. Put the base ring on sj4000, and screw the adapter on the ring.

Notes

  1. Could hold a sj4000 with a 3 mm projected (from the sheath) lens.
  2. This adapter is more stable than things from shopping websites, but will still loose if you pull it directly.
  3. Pull it directly if you gonna disassemble it, don't try to screw it back.
  4. This will wearing the panel of sj4000.

title: Dipping machine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This machine was a test machine that can dip objects into a solution for coating or cleaning. It works well but the dipping space is not that large, hard to use when the object is large or the beaker is large and the dipping drifts as its gets dipped because of how it works. It was a test to see the problems with making a dip coater.
http://tinkersprojects.com/project/dipping-machine/

see more what I have done: http://tinkersprojects.com/

Operation:
After powering the mill with 12V DC power, settings can be seen/changed using the LCD and can be altered using the 3 buttons (up, down and enter). Speed and height are the 2 settings that can be set to control the dip. While running, By pressing the enter button, the dip will reset.

parts list:
1 x PLEX controller
1 x 28byj-48 stepper motor
1 x Gt2 Timing Belt
3 x limit switch interrupt
2 x 20mm M3 screw
2 x 20mm M3 screw
4 x M3 nuts
1 x acrylic base
4 x rubber feet

Controller:
The controller used is the PLEX board from http://plexcontroller.com. The controller Uses a 16x2 LCD and buttons inputs to set settings display speed/distance while in operation. The limit switch is the reset the dipper to a set hight for dipping, this is that starting point of each dip. The controller sends a pulse to the stepper motor to make the dipping arm go up and down.

title: Lords of Waterdeep - Adventurer Token Collection

description.text:
An alternative set of adventurer tokens to replace the ones that come with the classic worker placement board game, Lords of Waterdeep. The unique shapes make them instantly recognizable, and have the added benefit of being colour blind friendly. Originally had the idea to make this set after searching here for LoW printables and only finding meeple alternatives. My own feelings on meeples aside, and despite the quality of what is available out there, I wanted to take my own crack on it.

The Fighter (Axe), Rogue (Lock), and Wizard (Spell-book) all need to be printed at a layer height no greater than 100μm due to curved/gradient surfaces. The Cleric (Ankh/Holy Symbol) may be printed at whatever height you wish.

Supports are not necessary, however if you are having issues printing the spell-book, try printing it standing upright with minimal support.

And that's about it.I started this project a year ago, and it's taken me a good deal of time to get round to actually finishing. I hope you enjoy the fruits of my labours (or lack-thereof). :)

title: DJI CrystalSky Monitor Mounting Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mounting bracket for the DJI CrystalSky display. It was originally designed for this console but might be useful in other mounting situations as well. The Fusion360 files are included in the download if you need to modify it for your needs.

In addition to the print you need two M5 screws to mount the display. I have included two printable thumbscrew heads. One for a hex and one for a cylinderhead screw.
I you use a cylinderhead screw, file down the head to form two parallel flats. This prevents the screw from rotating in the plastic part. The optimal width to file to is 5.5mm

The bracket has recesses for rubber pads. You can either print these with TPU or cut them from 1mm rubber sheet as I did.

Apart from that you only need 2-3 M3 screws to mount the bracket to the console.

There are two versions of the bracket in the download. The only difference is that one has thinner walls. This one should be plenty strong enough as well but I haven't printed and tested it yet.

Happy Printing.

Scaled down to the size for 5 lbs of thrust, these pieces would be printed and glued / bolted together. Parts would be printed in the orientation shown in the disassembled snapshot, with no supports. Two tailpipe pieces would glue onto the combustion chamber. The petal valves would bolt through the valve plate into the intake cone by self-tapping an M3 screw into the hole. These parts would then bolt onto the combustion chamber using M3 screws, and a short piece of rubber hose would be used for clamping a small carburetor to the intake, such as from a moped or other small engine. It is suggested to print the petal valves from a semi-flexible material such as TPU or Ninjatek Cheetah or Armadillo filament.

For starting the engine, with the carburetor ready to flow fuel you would apply a vacuum cleaner to the tailpipe of the engine to draw the air/fuel mix through. For ignition, it might need to be something like a pair of sewing pins heated and pushed through into the combustion chamber until they nearly touch, and then on the outside hook wires from those to an electric grill ignition button.

Note that there is a non-zero chance that your vacuum cleaner may explode if it draws too much air/fuel mix in and any of that sees a spark from the vacuum's motor. Always make sure to follow safety rules regarding playing with fire, have an extinguisher ready, and most important of all whatever you do, make sure to film it!

It is only expected that this engine would run for a few seconds before melting apart at the tailpipe, but if it can run self-sustaining for even a moment that would be a success. If a person were to print this with sparse fill from a water-tight filament, it might be possible to increase engine life by pouring water in and letting it freeze so that it has an ice jacket inside of the printed engine parts. But again, the point is just to see if the dimensions are correct to make it possible to get the sustained pulse jet combustion cycle to occur.

I will try to get one printed and tested soon, and will update with results.

Update 30DEC2017: Uploaded new .stl files in mm to avoid loss of quality in model when having to scale in slicer program from English to Metric. ChamberXL added which will only need a single tailpipe extension as it is taller, since my Rostock Max V3 can handle it. Attempting to print from PETG tonight.

Update 02JAN2018: After wiring up an ignition system and adding a carburetor and fuel system, we performed a few tests trying to start the engine. We used a vacuum on the tailpipe to prime the motor, drawing air/fuel through the carburetor to then be ignited electrically inside the engine. We did get one double-bang which I believe was the engine just barely trying to run, otherwise most were single bang's or a sustained flame only while the vacuum was on the tailpipe. Eventually everything melted apart before I could get the carburetor tuned and/or the vacuum method applied correct to get it to actually start running. But it definitely motivates us to move forward with the bigger project (see my other design for a 50lb thrust version made from welded sheet metal).

Before you print!

I recommend PLA for this print.
Requirements: Acrylic sheets, 32(you can use less) M3 screws longer that 1cm with nuts.

Assembly
1 - Once printed position the parts as in the image.
2 - Cut out and from any material a bottom plate and attach it (this is important - it will hold all the parts together)
3 - Place the power supply in its position
4 - Place the mother board in its place and wire it up
5 - You can start attaching the side plates
6 - attach the screen to the motherboard and place it in the screen holder on the frame.
7 - Take notes on any modifications you would do and post them here :)

Thank You very much for choosing this case for your printer :)

title: Vintage Hughes Aircraft Co Sign Litho

description.text:
So here's a cool sign from a better time. I made up probably about 30 of these vintage U.S. aircraft industry related sign lithos and thought I'd share 'em with yall. They are far from perfect and admittedly pretty simple, but they suit my purposes just fine. Some I'm gonna print small and put 'em with my scale aircraft collection and some of them will be printed big and hung on the shop wall somewhere. Now YOU can do something with 'em too!

This first one is the old style Hughes Aircraft Co sign. Howard Hughes was a bonafide genius and one hell of a model American, but his sign design is kinda, eh. He was probably busy building the H-1 Racer and banging Jean Harlow at the time, so I reckon he gets a pass!

comments.text: Well, not in any numbers, but they made the H-1 Racer, the H-4 Hercules, two XF-11's, and customized plenty of one-off planes and automobiles for Mr. Hughes. Their big game was weaponry and Helicopters, but that came much later, and their bigger game was dodging Tool Co's board of directors and others by incorporating Hughes Aircraft as a standalone division. Thats the popular tale anyhow. Kudos to 'em, sounds like The American Dream in action to me!

title: X-Cable Chain Motor Mount for Prusa-i3 Clone

description.text:
First of all thanks to daveposh for supplying a CAD file of another x-motor mount version.
Also many thanks to Seragon Python for his version / design of the cable chain and all parts that go with this. But mostly thanks to David Barré on which my version of X-Motor Mount bracket is based on.

Spent hours looking for a suitable X-Motor mounting bracket for a cable chain suitable for my Prusa-i3 clone. Yet as my unit has a strengthened bracket already, any designs out there wouldn't fit over / onto it. So had to design my own.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

After I had the basic design done I've realised it needed some supports for printing. Yet the supports done with Slic3r appeared to be rather messy which I didn't like. So I've decided to make my own. - These are the red bits in one of the drawings above which you will have to snap off after printing-
However, then slicer didn't like my new design with supports and simply left some bits out in the g-code. So as a consequence I ended up using CuraEngine. And turned out rather well. Used PLA+ for this one and the chain.
Motor mount requires slightly longer screws when installing this bracket.

Update: 14.1.18
Found motor mount was hard up against z bearing and also caused cable chain to be very close to filament.
This version - 2.2 - is slightly longer than the original and hence allows for free movement of the cable chain and larger gap to filament.

  • Not very neat but gets the job done - (was a cut & paste job)

Design fun ......or headache ???

Played around with FreeCad but ended up doing most on TinkerCAD.

author: mrminhghi

print_settings.Notes:: At least 4 perimeters (6 for PETG)

title: Flexion HT Extruder for the Prusa i3 MK2S

description.text:
IMPORTANT: The Prusa/E3D hotend cartridge thermistor does not fit in the Flexion hot ends. You can use a NTC 3950 100K Thermistor as a drop-in replacement however - your MK2S will never know the difference.

This is a complete extruder and hotend holder design that allows you to mount a Flexion or Flexion HT for i3 style printers for use with your Prusa i3 mk2/s. No special hardware is needed, you can reuse the fasteners you'll obtain from the old extruder body.

I've attempted to make this feel as 'native' to the mk2s as possible, to the point that you can even use the original fan nozzle. It mounts on the stock x-carriage and no parts need to be altered or swapped out, save for the extruder body and extruder cover.

The convective paths for air cooling have been planned carefully, and you should be able to access the full temperature range of the Flexion HT hotend without any plastic parts sagging or deforming even when using PETG.

There is one caveat, and that is that you will lose 12mm of build area along the Y-axis. This is, unfortunately, unavoidable due to stepper motor clearance issues on the extruder. Personally, it's a small price to pay. To compensate for this, see the final step at the end of this page/assembly guide.

Compatible with the regular Flexion as well as the Flexion HT upgrade. Single extruder only. NOT for the E3D version of the Flexion.

If you've been using one of the Noctua hotend fan upgrades, then by all means, continue to use it! :D They should be totally compatible with this new extruder.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.35mm

Infill:

40-50%

Notes:

Print in any of these materials:

  • ABS
  • PETG* (see notes below)
  • Polycarbonate

Use:

  • At least 4 perimeters (6 for PETG)
  • A strong infill pattern like triangles, hexagons, cubic, or 3D hexagons
  • Have bridging turned on in your slicer
  • No supports
  • At least 40% infill. This might sound like a lot, but these parts don't have much infill volume. The difference between 20% and 40% infill is about 8 grams of plastic, but you get a lot of rigidity in return.
  • Layer height doesn't really matter, 0.35 still resolves everything well enough and prints nice and fast.

Assembly Instructions

Note: This assumes you have already completed the removal of your old extruder from the x-axis carriage, and have followed Flexion's assembly instructions through step 6. It is also very important to not skip putting a length of PLA filament (it must be PLA) into the extruder before you tighten the set screws of the hobbed gear. The hard PLA filament will correctly align the hobbed gear with the idler wheel, and if it is even slightly off, extruder performance will suffer significantly. I know, because I skipped this step the first time :).

Make sure both set screws are unreasonably tight, then tighten them another quarter turn.

Step 1

You will need the following fasteners (all of which you should have already from removing and disassembling the old extruder):

1 x M3x40 screw
3 x M3x30 screws
2 x M3x20 screws
4 x M3x18 screws
1 x M3x12 screw

3 x M3 square nuts
4 x M3 hex nuts

Allright, let's start!

Attach the heatsink to the extruder cover using a M3x12 socket screw as shown in the photos. An M3x14 might work as well, but make sure it doesn't block the hole that is at a right angle on the heatsink when screwed all the way in.

No screw yet A single M3x12 screw is screwed into the bottom of the heatsink. Step 2

Rest the Flexion + extruder motor assembly you made earlier on its back, and place the extruder cover and heatsink assembly over the face of the motor, with the heatsink fins pointing outwards away from the motor face. Basically, you're just positioning the heatsink where it would be mounted normally (on the lower two stepper motor mounting holes), but with the extruder body attached to the heatsink.

Sliding the heatsink over the motor. Line up the holes. Step 3

Using an M3x30 screw, attach the heatsink and extruder body to the front of the stepper motor.

The screw in question can be seen near the top. Step 4

Slide the assembly into the extruder body, as shown.

Step 5

Place a square nut in the nut trap located on the bottom, as shown.

Step 6

Place a second square nut in the second nut trap, which is on the opposite end of the extruder:

Step 7

Locate the two socket screw holes on the extruder cover that align with the two square nuts you just inserted. Use 2 M3x30 socket screws to attach the extruder body and extruder cover together. Make sure these screws are nice and tight.

Step 8

Keep all your cabling how it was originally, except for the extruder motor cable, which must be run up and over the top of the x-carraige.

There are 3 nut traps that are used to attach the extruder body to the x-carriage. They can be found by looking along the axis of the 3 mounting holes on the back of the extruder body. There are 2 hex nut traps on the non-motor side, and a single square nut trap on the motor side. Place a nut in each trap.

Now, using 3 screws of your discretion, mount the extruder to the x-carriage exactly like the original extruder was mounted. The 3 holes can handle several different screw lengths, so as long as you chose screws that are long enough to reach their respective nut, there is no problem. I ended up having to use screws a bit long, but that's ok. There are clearance holes that go beyond the nut traps that can accept over-length screws without issue.

First non-motor side trap (with nut added). Second non-motor side nut trap, located beneath the hotend cooling fan bracket. Motor side trap. Step 9

Now mount the PINDA probe, blower fan, hotend fan, and fan nozzle exactly like you would on the original extruder. Their locations are all exactly the same. Note, only one of the two screw and square nut pairs are needed for the PINDA probe. There are small wedge braces that will keep it rigid and in position with just the screw and nut closest to the print bed holding it in place. The holes for the hotend fan and one of the blower fan holes are self-tapping and don't need a nut. The other blower fan hole uses a nut in an identical fashion to the original extruder.

For more rigidity, you can use an extra long M3x45 screw in place of one of the shorter screws when attaching the hotend fan, so it goes all the way through the heatsink to finally attach directly to the stepper motor. In my experience, this isn't really necessary but it probably won't make things worse either. If you use a noctua fan adapter, then you can use an M3x40 screw.

All done!

Sit back, relax, bask in your new high-performance extruder from Diabase Engineering!

Well, we're almost done. Make sure to follow the rest Flexion's assembly instructions for tightening the cam screw and attaching/assembling the hotend. No disassembly of the extruder will be needed to complete the remainder of Flexion's assembly instructions.

When using this extruder mount, please add this gcode to the 'start script' of your prints in your favorite slicer. This is to compensate for the lost y-axis:

G1 Y12 F1500 ; move to Y=12
G92 Y0 ; set this position as new Y0

The flexion extruder has a different hobbed gear radius, so we need to change the steps per mm of our extruder stepper motor to around 94.54. That number worked well for me, but if you want to be really precise, doing an extruder calibration is best.

M92 E94.54 ; Set extruder steps per mm to 94.54
M500 ; Save settings to the EEPROM

The above will semi-permanently change the extruder steps per mm, allowing things like loading and unloading filament to occur at the right speed, and you can keep using all your same extruder multipliers as is. If you do a hard reset of all data on your printer, you might need to send:

M501 ;  This will restore the saved EEPROM settings

If you change your mind and want to use the stock extruder, send:

M502 ; This will reset the extruder to the stock Prusa one.

Don't forget to do a full XYZ and first layer recalibration.

comments.author: Radekn4

description.text:
I AM PLANNING TO RE-DO THIS SOON

A model of Walschaerts Valve Gear, used in steam locomotives.

Included are all the base components individually, including the pins to hold it all together. The pins are just placeholders really, I recommend using actual metal pins or adjusting the design slightly so the pins work better. I purposefully left large gaps in between components so that inaccuracy in a 3D Print can be made up for. Better to have parts that fit loose rather than not fit at all.

Also included is the base Fusion 360 Model, so you can make adjustments if you wish, or see the process of how it was made.

The expansion link is quite roughly done, it's just functional (I hope) and not pretty or precise.

I have marked the design a Work in Progress, as I am currently attempting to 3D Print it myself just to see if it actually works, no guarantee that is does currently. Once I see how it all goes I will update the page accordingly.

The scale is such that it can be printed on an Ultimaker 2 Extended+, the printer which I use.

I recommend using a wooden base plate, with tighter tolerances that what I have used here.

Made in Fusion 360.

If you want the design modified in any way, let me know and I'll see what I can do.

Email: [email protected]
Twitter: https://twitter.com/Striker_Raiser

description.text:
This is adapter for standalone server power supply Dell DPS-670. This one need some cooling so I added 80mm fan that is connected to 12V output. To make it running you need to short pin 4 and 23 to the ground (pins 9-12).
Pins go like this:
1 5 9 13 17 21
2 6 10 14 18 22
3 7 11 15 19 23
4 8 12 16 20 24

Copper blades next to the pins (1-3) are GND and 4-6 are 12V.

Works great for my RC charger :)

title: Sonicmodell HD Wind Landing skid protector set

description.text:
READ THE UPDATE This is only the design for the front landing skid. It has never been printed yet in order to make necessary corrections for proper fit.(Work in Progress)
Since we print with Z-Ultra T filament that is even stronger than ABS and with a minimal amount of warp, this part should be tested if you want from PLA and theoretically it will fit.

Update January 8th 2017. I deleted the original file since it was completely wrong and uploaded only the fuselage bottom skid. You will need to print 2 of those and glue them on to protect your foam. As soon as parts are epoxy dry i will upload some pictures.

Update January 9th 2017. Fuselage Rear skid landing protector uploaded. same print settings.

Update January 9th 2017 V2.0. After having the wing protector printer i found that it fits also on the outer wind skid and renamed the file.

You will need to print 2pcs of Fuselage Front Skid, 1pcs Fuselage Rear and 4pcs Wing. Now your HD/Skyray or what ever name you have it will be a little more protected during landing.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Z-Ultra T material by Zortrax.
First layer at 260C and 90C bed and remaining layers at 265C with 95C bed.
Our printers are in a steady 30C enclosure and i will use a cooling fan set to auto from 8-15% after the first 3 layers of the print.
2 outer layers, 2 bottom, 2 top and 15% rectilinear infill.
Designed in Tinkercad so accuracy might not be perfect.

title: Aurora 90 V1 outer strut
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I built up an Aurora 90 a while back, knowing the struts could be an issue. Even after adding 1mm thick spacers underneath the motors, props still managed to strike them in a hard enough tumble. Eachine released a V1.1 which added additional clearance but required new set of ducts and struts that were still installed inside the new prop guard. I decided to model a strut that mounts outside to get it totally out of the way.

Printer:

MonoPrice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15-0.25mm

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

Rotate and lay flat when printing, use 3-4 perimeters for a really strong part. Lower layer heights will preserve the rounded look, but thicker layers to tend to be stronger. Testing mine in Inland PLA at the moment but ABS, PETG or Nylon would probably be better for durability.

Recommended pre-threading the screws, they fit quite snug on the ones I printed in PLA. Use the stock countersunk screws or get some M2 4mm length button or cap head screws (I ordered aluminum screws from http://www.fastener-express.com in an effort to shave weight).

Fusion 360, calipers and a lot of eyeballing and test fitting! I wanted to make sure the prop guards would be in the same location of the alloy parts were used, without the supports they tend to sag slightly at the corners.

author: Archimedus

title: Bidirectional Keyboard Feet for Cheaper Keyboards - Easy to Print

description.text:
These are bi-directional keyboard feet/stands for cheaper keyboards that you can find all over the place. Just print these twice and designed to be very easy to print even on inaccurate printers and requires no support. Just print them with about 30% infill and you'll end up with some strong feet.

These are a little less than 1 inch wide (not counting the pins) or about 24mm. In terms of length they are about 26mm.

I've provided two designs, the only difference being the pins. It's about 3mm for each in one and 2.4mm in the standard version. You could just print the longer pin version and trim them with a nail cutter.

Enjoy!

author: Archimedus

title: WWII Era Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Engines Sign Litho

description.text:
Here's the world famous Pratt & Whitney Dependable Engines logo. I think this file turned out fine, and it should print nicely. I'm going to make at least a couple of these myself. I would have to think that the P & W radial engines are in the top five list of machines that we couldn't have won the war without. Right up there with the Willys and the DC-3. They're power houses, they sound great, and they are still running to this very moment the whole world over. It doesn't get much better than that!

This is the last one of these I'm posting for now. I have 21 (!) more that I made and they'll get uploaded throughout the week.

A larger version of a parabolic mic, much improved acoustics vs. my prior model. Prints well on a 200x200mm bed. Print it relatively solid, since sound reflects better off hard surfaces.

You will need several M3 5mm screws, four M3 20mm screws, locking M3 nuts, and a lapel microphone.

Test 1: Small stream waterfall. First 10 seconds are with just a microphone. Last 10 seconds are with the parabolic mic setup. The difference is dramatic.
https://youtu.be/C6U8m3roYoE

Test 2: Witness the disgusting self-hygiene sounds of the pug. The first 10 seconds were recorded through the parabolic mic, and the last 8 seconds with just the lapel mic: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2isji7mE3Ik

Notes: Obviously to be printed with NinjaFlex. Any stringing is because I turned off retraction. The dimensions are made so that it fits perfectly within a 12 stud brick. I've included the Sketchup file in case anyone wants to change it.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/052kRwd5huw

This is an extremely accurate fan-made replica of the TARDIS key as used in the 1996 Doctor Who TV movie, featuring Paul McGann as the Eighth Doctor.

The key prop used in the film was an official TARDIS key replica available at the time from 800-Trekker, a now-long-defunct scifi memorabilia catalog, under license from the BBC in the early 1990s. The 800-Trekker key was a unique design largely based on TARDIS keys used on-screen by the Third and Fourth Doctors in the 1970s, but with many noticeable differences from those TV props. Rather than design a new TARDIS key for the 1996 film, the film's prop department just bought a supply of those keys from 800-Trekker and made them the canonical key design used by the Seventh and Eighth Doctors in their movie.

The newly-canonical 800-Trekker keys became very popular with fans, but had already been out of production and in limited supply by the film's release. They were also made of a very soft pewter which scratched and bent easily, so very few good copies of the Trekker key remain in circulation today. I happen to own one of the Trekker keys, ordered myself from the catalog around 20 years ago. Armed with calipers, 3D software, and a desire to replace my prop (which has begun to show noticeable wear, despite my best efforts to preserve it) with something more durable, I painstakingly recreated this key based on it.

My key does have some infinitesimal differences from the prop. Perfect circles on my version may have been slightly elliptical on the original, and my version lacks the mold lines present along the edges of the original. Wherever it came down to a choice between duplicating imperfections in the original's casting process versus using the exact geometric nature of 3D design and printing to its fullest, I've chosen the more clean-looking route.

So, here's what I feel is the neatest replica of the Eighth Doctor key you can find! Please share, enjoy, and have fun with it.

Please note that if you plan to put this on a necklace, keychain, or similar, the hole in the key is only 3mm in diameter. For most chains, this means you'll have to add a small wire loop to the hole which the chain can fit through. This was done on the original Trekker keys, and such a loop appears on the film prop. You can get them from craft supply shops, or take one from an old keychain or pendant.

If you'd like to buy this key printed in metal (or other interesting materials) on high-res industrial-grade equipment, following this link to my Shapeways shop and buying it there would be very cool of you. Examples of Shapeways metal prints can be seen in the photos here.

comments.text: The idea of duplicating this key has fascinated me since I got one 1986 (predates the movie, used in Tom Baker as the Doctor years) but looks the same. Thanks.

description.text: A printable dial counter, like the old style odometers. Arbitrary number of digits possible in theory though slop in the parts may create a practical limit.

Tools required: A set of needle files (and maybe one normal file for more aggressive material removal) and/or sandpaper. These parts are designed to be assembled without glue or fasteners and how well they fit will depend on your printer's abilities. You will probably need to at least remove burrs and strings for good fit. Hopefully that are just a hair too tight and you can file them down. Instructions: Determine the number of digits you will want. We will call this N. Print N of:
1) Number Wheel Print N-1 of:
1) Axle Plate
2) Geneva Wheel
3) Pinion Print 1 each of:
1) First digit cap
2) Last Digit cap Alternate: You may also use an additional axle plate(s) instead of the cap(s) on either end. I made the caps to save material and reduce print time. Once everything is printed, tidy them up and assemble! Refer to the rendering to see how it all goes together. This assembly has small features and might not turn out so well for larger nozzles or less-tuned machines... but please share your success/failure stories! Video in action: http://youtu.be/tbzUhtlWPW0

title: Spool Holder / Stand for 3D Printer, 608zz Bearing

description.text:
Simple spool holder/stand using four 608zz (7mm x 8mm x 22mm) bearings. UPDATED: added a bit more space between bearing and bottom and reduced the chamfer size.

I designed the stand with reference to a spool with a diameter of 200mm, but it should work for other spools as well.

I added some grooves at the bottom for easy removal and some fins (feet) for improved stability. Obviously, you need four bearings, four pins, and two holders, which should snap into each other pretty tightly. If necessary, a touch of super glue won't hurt.

This is intended to be an entry-level design project for students to learn about basic sketching, constraints, patterns, projection, extrusion, tolerances, etc.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

description.text:
This is RIFRAF Carcassonne, The Festivals Full Set
Printed on a single extruder printer. No two tiles are alike, all custom made with a “c” inlay and 3d texture to the fields and city floor... There is very little to paint, I used 8 different colors of PLA filament and was very precise in my layering. You can see I had some stringing issues with some filament in the pictures, unfortunately the PLA was not the best quality.
Great thanks to all who went before with their developing this game and the many parts. There are dozens of “pieces” from others ideas assembled and added to here. Without the pioneers gone before us we would not be here today. Enjoy!
The compete set is finished here, see Rifraf Carcassonne…the River, Festivals, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, Abbey & Mayor, The Princess & the Dragon, and The Tower Under the Big Top and Hills and Sheep in my other posts, over 240 Tiles total.
The Original Set: 72 Tiles
The River: 12 Tiles
Festivals: 10 Tiles
Inns & Cathedrals: 18 Tiles
Traders & Builders: 24 Tiles
Abbey & Mayor: 18 Tiles
The Princess & the Dragon: 30 Tiles
The Tower: 18 Tiles
Under the Big Top: 20 Game Tiles
Hills and Sheep: 18 Tiles
How I printed: On a Prusa i3 MK2 in all PLA with a base height of .200mm and a layer height of .150 with a 4mm nozzle. 4 Base layers and 3 top layers, 15% Cubic infill with a CONCENTRIC Top/Bottom fill pattern, This is important if you want the same layer divisions and “style”. I printed with a 3mm brim attached to all tiles, I found if I did not I got the occasional corner lift, but it did mean I had to trim the sides of all the tiles.
What I painted: The tops of the farm and city houses..RED, the 6 Volcano and 6 “portal” tiles from The Princess and the Dragon…GREY, and the filled in the garden squares using a toothpick and 4 different paints for the flowers…and the tops of the festival tents…That’s it…(there are 2 tiles in The Princess & Dragon that have the cloisters AND emblems, you will have to decide between painting the cloister or wall top towers)..that is if you print the way I did.
Some issues and tips: This is very important…When slicing in Slic3r sometimes the tiles would not render with the correct number of top layers, for example the roads would only have a layer or two finished and then the fill would show through…or the fields would not have all the layers… for some reason, rotating the affected tile 90 degrees on the plate sometimes a couple times and then reslicing fixed this issue…do a good preview check to examine how your layers are printing… it was a ton of wasted prints for me to work this out.
The very base layer has the “C” cut out, if you make your base layer one color, then change to a different color for the next few layers the filament with just “flow” into this space and it looks like you have a nice inlay…it does not affect the rest of the printing in any way… this is the “poor man’s inlay trick”…also the concentric fill pattern on the bottom gives it the “scattered” look sort of like the original tiles.
The fields have a darker layer under the light green, this adds to the textured look, also the City floor has a Dark brown layer followed by two copper layers for the “cobble stone” look, you can experiment with different color materials for enhance the “3d” look of these areas.
I have not printed all the Princess & the Dragon, Under the Big Top, or Traders & Builders or Hills and Sheep…I ran out of filament... .. they look good but if they are anything like the rest of the tiles I will have to go back to correct an item or two.. Please let me know.
The Towers are designed to fit snug.
My Printing and colors: (How you slice will of course change any of these) I used Prusa Color print to define the layers.
For all tiles except the ones with a Cloister, the Cathedrals, and the Abbeys
0-.35 Light Green (The Base color, will be shaded according to the subsequent layers)
.35-1.1 Blue (For the base of the ponds)
1.1-20 Skin (for the base of the roads)(may have to be 1.25-2.0)
2.0-2.3 Copper (for the underlay dark field color)
2.3-3.2 Light Green (for the fields)
3.2-3.35 Dark Brown (for the underlay of the city floor)
3.35-3.35 Copper (for the city floor)
3.65 -4.1 Pearl White (for the base of the shields and emblems)
4.1-4.55 Blue (for the shield and emblem tops)
4.55-8.15 Khaki (for the walls)
8.15---- Blue (for the wall tops and towers)

For the Cloisters: Same to start then 3.65-9.95 is Khaki and then 9.95 and on is RED
For the Cathedrals and Abbey: Same to start then 3.65-13.40 Khaki and then 13.40 and on is RED

Your choices and colors will vary according to what you deicide.. this is just what I did. Have Fun, and if it works for you please send me a "LIKE"

title: Parametric RAMPS 1.4 Enclosure with Offset Mounting

description.text: This is a parametric RAMPS enclosure with various tunable parameters. The included STLs are specifically for a RAMPS 1.4 with LCD board and a 40mm fan mounted on the interior top, with a mounting offset for a SeeMeCNC LaserCut Prusa i3 frame. The SCAD is easy to edit for other setups. This enclosure provides 4 screw mounts on the rear of the box to secure your RAMPS board. Once mounted the plugs should align to the bottom openings. There's a slot on the rear side of the box to pass through all your printer control wires, keeping wires out of the way while allowing you to shift things around. By default a 40mm fan mounts on the inside-top, pulling air from below. This box has separate mounting holes for the box itself. This is a tunable offset, originally intended to move the box out of the way of my X motor. The exterior risers ensure that the box clears the bottom threaded rod on my i3. The space behind the box is useful for the x endstop and motor wires to pass through. When the box or lid are printed in translucent PLA it gives the status lights a cool glowing effect. This design is open source. Help make it better at https://github.com/thinkyhead/ramps-box-i3

There are two options for making this box. You can make the whole box, plus the cover, or you can make all the sides separately, then glue them together (and still also make the cover). The box should be reliably printable as a single part on a well-tuned RepRap, but printing all the pieces flat makes better walls. If you decide to go that way, I recommend using hot glue for PLA, or superglue and acetone for ABS.  
The cover is intended to snap on and be relatively easy to pull off when you need it open. If the clips don't hold perfectly, you can put tape over them to fatten them up, or try printing wider clips by messing with the SCAD file.  
Notice that the SCAD files are set up in a cool way. Each file renders as a separate part when opened in a SCAD editor, but the "whole" file includes an override before including all the parts, so they align to the right position for the full box. A simple trick, but one that makes it easier to split up parts into separate files that each manage their own stuff.

comments.text: A small fan should do fine. Even a little bit of airflow will help a lot. If your stepper drivers have heatsinks on them then the fan is more just insurance than anything. If you are in a very warm climate, run the fan at high speed. (The fan I use in mine actually runs too fast at a full 12V so I have a resistor inline to slow it down. Of course this adds a little bit of heat, but it's on the right side, so, far from the stepper drivers.)

author: tomasf

description.text:
Cue the evil laughter... Yes, its a functional laser bandsaw!

First things first: this is not a toy, but it is presented purely for your amusement. If you choose to do something with this material, be warned: this device is hazardous! The laser can burn/cut you and ruin your vision! I have made a first cut at a suitable guard for this, but its a DRAFT of a guard, and needs work. You must ALSO wear laser goggles!

After listening to Max and Justin on the Home Shop Machinist Podcast talking about the next 100 years of home shop machine tools and the "laser bandsaw" I, of course, had to build one!
https://thecogwheel.net/2017/10/01/home-shop-machinists-podcast-episode-11-shop-of-the-future/

The laser is a NUBM44 installed in a Copper housing. The heat sink is totally custom made with about 0.002" of clearance between the housing and heat sink for heat sink paste. A Super X-drive (designed by Laseerer) powers the laser. I had fun boring out the hole to match the diode housing (tiny little boring bar) and cutting fins into it with a slitting saw. A pocket under the fan allows air to reach the fins, and the ends of the fins are sealed with Aluminum foil tape so that all the air exits around the lens and provides some air assist.

The black rectangle under the laser is the beam dump: a stack of box knife blades. You need this because the laser is on continuously, and you need a place for that energy to go SAFELY! The orange shielding material is from JTech Photonics, hot formed to fit around the laser heat sink. I cheated some and masked areas of the acrylic that I didn't want to have bend by using more Aluminum foil tape. That stuff is great, if irritatingly sharp!

To set it up, feed it a small current (under half an Amp, which will require around 4-5 Volts to get the diode to turn on). Put a sheet of paper on the table and adjust for minimum spot size (you are wearing your goggles, right?!?).

In use, move your target object through the beam slowly and it will cut! Paper and business cards cut pretty well. Single layer cardboard cuts ok-ish. Double layer mostly just burns. It will take black paint/ink off of stuff really fast. Craft foam and felt both cut well, if a bit stinky. Balsa cuts really fast and nicely!

I've got a higher resolution video on YouTube: https://youtu.be/1sBeiYIkn4k

comments.text: This is both incredible and terrifying. Overall I think it's a super useful tool, it's like a scroll saw with no blade that can cut very clean. The safety precautions you took are good, but laser safety is important to be thorough with. Kudos on the originality, I don't think this has been done before. Although why do I suspect this has been in a Neal Stephenson book?
comments.author: portcitymakerspace_3270

comments.text: I totally agree!  This is merely a proof-of-concept to see if it could possibly be done.  Unfortunately, at this power level its not actually very useful; lots of burning of the edges and un-impressive cutting on many things.  Fun, though!

author: GONGGAM

description.text:
This is RIFRAF Carcassonne, The Abbey & Mayor Full Set
Printed on a single extruder printer. No two tiles are alike, all custom made with a “c” inlay and 3d texture to the fields and city floor... There is very little to paint, I used 8 different colors of PLA filament and was very precise in my layering. You can see I had some stringing issues with some filament in the pictures, unfortunately the PLA was not the best quality.
Great thanks to all who went before with their developing this game and the many parts. There are dozens of “pieces” from others ideas assembled and added to here. Without the pioneers gone before us we would not be here today. Enjoy!
The compete Base set is finished here, see Rifraf Carcassonne…the River, Festivals, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, Abbey & Mayor, The Princess & the Dragon, and The Tower, Under the Big Top and Hills and Sheep in my other posts, over 240 Tiles total.
The Original Set: 72 Tiles
The River: 12 Tiles
Festivals: 10 Tiles
Inns & Cathedrals: 18 Tiles
Traders & Builders: 24 Tiles
Abbey & Mayor: 18 Tiles
The Princess & the Dragon: 30 Tiles
The Tower: 18 Tiles
Under the Big Top: 20 Game Tiles
Hills and Sheep: 18 Tiles
How I printed: On a Prusa i3 MK2 in all PLA with a base height of .200mm and a layer height of .150 with a 4mm nozzle. 4 Base layers and 3 top layers, 15% Cubic infill with a CONCENTRIC Top/Bottom fill pattern, This is important if you want the same layer divisions and “style”. I printed with a 3mm brim attached to all tiles, I found if I did not I got the occasional corner lift, but it did mean I had to trim the sides of all the tiles.
What I painted: The tops of the farm and city houses..RED, the 6 Volcano and 6 “portal” tiles from The Princess and the Dragon…GREY, and the filled in the garden squares using a toothpick and 4 different paints for the flowers…and the tops of the festival tents…That’s it…(there are 2 tiles in The Princess & Dragon that have the cloisters AND emblems, you will have to decide between painting the cloister or wall top towers)..that is if you print the way I did.
Some issues and tips: This is very important…When slicing in Slic3r sometimes the tiles would not render with the correct number of top layers, for example the roads would only have a layer or two finished and then the fill would show through…or the fields would not have all the layers… for some reason, rotating the affected tile 90 degrees on the plate sometimes a couple times and then reslicing fixed this issue…do a good preview check to examine how your layers are printing… it was a ton of wasted prints for me to work this out.
The very base layer has the “C” cut out, if you make your base layer one color, then change to a different color for the next few layers the filament with just “flow” into this space and it looks like you have a nice inlay…it does not affect the rest of the printing in any way… this is the “poor man’s inlay trick”…also the concentric fill pattern on the bottom gives it the “scattered” look sort of like the original tiles.
The fields have a darker layer under the light green, this adds to the textured look, also the City floor has a Dark brown layer followed by two copper layers for the “cobble stone” look, you can experiment with different color materials for enhance the “3d” look of these areas.
I have not printed all the Princess & the Dragon, Under the Big Top or Traders & Builders or Hills and Sheep…I ran out of filament... .. they look good but if they are anything like the rest of the tiles I will have to go back to correct an item or two.. Please let me know.
The Towers are designed to fit snug.
My Printing and colors: (How you slice will of course change any of these) I used Prusa Color print to define the layers.
For all tiles except the ones with a Cloister, the Cathedrals, and the Abbeys
0-.35 Light Green (The Base color, will be shaded according to the subsequent layers)
.35-1.1 Blue (For the base of the ponds)
1.1-20 Skin (for the base of the roads)(may have to be 1.25-2.0)
2.0-2.3 Copper (for the underlay dark field color)
2.3-3.2 Light Green (for the fields)
3.2-3.35 Dark Brown (for the underlay of the city floor)
3.35-3.35 Copper (for the city floor)
3.65 -4.1 Pearl White (for the base of the shields and emblems)
4.1-4.55 Blue (for the shield and emblem tops)
4.55-8.15 Khaki (for the walls)
8.15---- Blue (for the wall tops and towers)

For the Cloisters: Same to start then 3.65-9.95 is Khaki and then 9.95 and on is RED
For the Cathedrals and Abbey: Same to start then 3.65-13.40 Khaki and then 13.40 and on is RED

Your choices and colors will vary according to what you deicide.. this is just what I did. Have Fun, and if it works for you please send me a "LIKE"

title: Dual Blower + 40mm Fan for Hypercube v1

description.text:
Made my own dual blower mount with a 40mm fan. Wanted to have my blowers get enough air flow so I kept the blowers higher up. So far it has performed really well. I printed them all at 0.2 layer height but they could be done anywhere up to 0.3mm. All printed in PETG.

I designed the mount to allow me to zip tie my cable wraps and have a more secure wiring harness. An E3D sock is necessary for this!

I think there is room for improvement so I'm dubbing this v1, hopefully I'll have time over the holidays to improve!

Also use the endstop piece so that the blower doesn't hit your motors when homing. Just snap it into the rods. So far I only have an 8mm version, if people need another I can make that happen.

P.S. I know my buildtak is messed up, I'm putting a glass bed on!

Hypercube

title: ePIc Droid  ID10 Star Wars Inspired raspberry pi 2 and 3 case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I started with just wanting a somewhat replica of the ID10 droid from the video game Star Wars Battlefront II. Once I had what I thought looked pretty good I started carving it apart to create a raspberry pi case. It turned out much better than I thought when I started so I am here to share it. Download it, try it out and be sure to come back and tip :) Please :) And if you cant afford a buck or 2 please share your makes at the very least. I do appreciate the love and happy to share :)

Features of the design:

Body can hold a raspberry Pi 2 or 3
Has mounting spot for a 40 x 40 x 10mm fan
Clearance inside nose cone to install an led running from your pi
Opening for 3mm jack, hdmi, and power plug ( you will need to buy low profile versions of these cords to fit in the cavity. More so the HDMI as the power cord has a lot of space.

HDMI that works awesome
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00T58JH98

Air inputs around the perimeter to allow airflow into the pi cavity
Also designed compatibility for a 90 Deg hdmi adapter to run hdmi out the bottom instead of side.
Universal mount system so if you want to mount just the droid portion without the legs in can easy be retro fitted.

Special notes:

Limited access to the GPIO pins.
No access to ribbon cable ports on pi through the case. I am pretty sure you could dremel some slots in there if you had to have specific access.

I wish I was more of a finisher because I think this could turn out unbelievable in the right hands and the proper finish.

Needed hardware:
A raspberry Pi 2 or 3 ( of course )
4 #4 x 3/8 screws to mount pi into body
3 #5 x 3/8-1/2 long screws to attach covers to body
4 3mm or equivalent x 1/2" long screws w corresponding nylock nuts to attach legs to body and legs to base or you can just tape the holes and use an 8- 32 screws

Optional :
40 x 40 x 10mm 5v fan
4 #4 x 3/8" long screws to mount fan
5mm led
You will want to run this of the 3v port on the pi

If you don't have the means to print one yourself you can get it from my shop here.

https://www.etsy.com/listing/578661805/

Printer:

Ft-5

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

The legs do need supports. Originally had made them articulating but decided they were better meant solid so they will have to be supported to print correctly.

The main body without my drawn in supports will need supports as well.

I created a flat on the back of the main body at 30 degrees to aid in printing. I found that this worked the best. I have a version with supports I drew in that I have had the best luck with. You just need to clear the lengths between the openings after printing is complete.

author: gmunson

description.text:
This is RIFRAF Carcassonne, The Tower Full Set
Printed on a single extruder printer. No two tiles are alike, all custom made with a “c” inlay and 3d texture to the fields and city floor... There is very little to paint, I used 8 different colors of PLA filament and was very precise in my layering. You can see I had some stringing issues with some filament in the pictures, unfortunately the PLA was not the best quality.
Great thanks to all who went before with their developing this game and the many parts. There are dozens of “pieces” from others ideas assembled and added to here. Without the pioneers gone before us we would not be here today. Enjoy!
The compete Base set is finished here, see Rifraf Carcassonne…the River, Festivals, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, Abbey & Mayor, The Princess & the Dragon, and The Tower, Under the Big Top and Hills and Sheep in my other posts, over 240 Tiles total.
The Original Set: 72 Tiles
The River: 12 Tiles
Festivals: 10 Tiles
Inns & Cathedrals: 18 Tiles
Traders & Builders: 24 Tiles
Abbey & Mayor: 18 Tiles
The Princess & the Dragon: 30 Tiles
The Tower: 18 Tiles
Under the Big Top: 20 Game Tiles
Hills and Sheep: 18 Tiles
How I printed: On a Prusa i3 MK2 in all PLA with a base height of .200mm and a layer height of .150 with a 4mm nozzle. 4 Base layers and 3 top layers, 15% Cubic infill with a CONCENTRIC Top/Bottom fill pattern, This is important if you want the same layer divisions and “style”. I printed with a 3mm brim attached to all tiles, I found if I did not I got the occasional corner lift, but it did mean I had to trim the sides of all the tiles.
What I painted: The tops of the farm and city houses..RED, the 6 Volcano and 6 “portal” tiles from The Princess and the Dragon…GREY, and the filled in the garden squares using a toothpick and 4 different paints for the flowers…and the tops of the festival tents…That’s it…(there are 2 tiles in The Princess & Dragon that have the cloisters AND emblems, you will have to decide between painting the cloister or wall top towers)..that is if you print the way I did.
Some issues and tips: This is very important…When slicing in Slic3r sometimes the tiles would not render with the correct number of top layers, for example the roads would only have a layer or two finished and then the fill would show through…or the fields would not have all the layers… for some reason, rotating the affected tile 90 degrees on the plate sometimes a couple times and then reslicing fixed this issue…do a good preview check to examine how your layers are printing… it was a ton of wasted prints for me to work this out.
The very base layer has the “C” cut out, if you make your base layer one color, then change to a different color for the next few layers the filament with just “flow” into this space and it looks like you have a nice inlay…it does not affect the rest of the printing in any way… this is the “poor man’s inlay trick”…also the concentric fill pattern on the bottom gives it the “scattered” look sort of like the original tiles.
The fields have a darker layer under the light green, this adds to the textured look, also the City floor has a Dark brown layer followed by two copper layers for the “cobble stone” look, you can experiment with different color materials for enhance the “3d” look of these areas.
I have not printed all the Princess & the Dragon, Under the Big Top, or Traders & Builders, or Hills and Sheep…I ran out of filament... .. they look good but if they are anything like the rest of the tiles I will have to go back to correct an item or two.. Please let me know.
The Towers are designed to fit snug.
My Printing and colors: (How you slice will of course change any of these) I used Prusa Color print to define the layers.
For all tiles except the ones with a Cloister, the Cathedrals, and the Abbeys
0-.35 Light Green (The Base color, will be shaded according to the subsequent layers)
.35-1.1 Blue (For the base of the ponds)
1.1-20 Skin (for the base of the roads)(may have to be 1.25-2.0)
2.0-2.3 Copper (for the underlay dark field color)
2.3-3.2 Light Green (for the fields)
3.2-3.35 Dark Brown (for the underlay of the city floor)
3.35-3.35 Copper (for the city floor)
3.65 -4.1 Pearl White (for the base of the shields and emblems)
4.1-4.55 Blue (for the shield and emblem tops)
4.55-8.15 Khaki (for the walls)
8.15---- Blue (for the wall tops and towers)

For the Cloisters: Same to start then 3.65-9.95 is Khaki and then 9.95 and on is RED
For the Cathedrals and Abbey: Same to start then 3.65-13.40 Khaki and then 13.40 and on is RED

Your choices and colors will vary according to what you deicide.. this is just what I did. Have Fun, and if it works for you please send me a "LIKE"

The Towers are designed to fit snug.
My Printing and colors: (How you slice will of course change any of these) I used Prusa Color print to define the layers.
For all tiles except the ones with a Cloister, the Cathedrals, and the Abbeys
0-.35 Light Green (The Base color, will be shaded according to the subsequent layers)
.35-1.1 Blue (For the base of the ponds)
1.1-20 Skin (for the base of the roads)(may have to be 1.25-2.0)
2.0-2.3 Copper (for the underlay dark field color)
2.3-3.2 Light Green (for the fields)
3.2-3.35 Dark Brown (for the underlay of the city floor)
3.35-3.35 Copper (for the city floor)
3.65 -4.1 Pearl White (for the base of the shields and emblems)
4.1-4.55 Blue (for the shield and emblem tops)
4.55-8.15 Khaki (for the walls)
8.15---- Blue (for the wall tops and towers)

For the Cloisters: Same to start then 3.65-9.95 is Khaki and then 9.95 and on is RED
For the Cathedrals and Abbey: Same to start then 3.65-13.40 Khaki and then 13.40 and on is RED

Your choices and colors will vary according to what you deicide.. this is just what I did. Have Fun, and if it works for you please send me a "LIKE"

description.text:
This is RIFRAF Carcassonne, Traders and Builders Full Set
Printed on a single extruder printer. No two tiles are alike, all custom made with a “c” inlay and 3d texture to the fields and city floor... There is very little to paint, I used 8 different colors of PLA filament and was very precise in my layering. You can see I had some stringing issues with some filament in the pictures, unfortunately the PLA was not the best quality.
Great thanks to all who went before with their developing this game and the many parts. There are dozens of “pieces” from others ideas assembled and added to here. Without the pioneers gone before us we would not be here today. Enjoy!
The compete Base set is finished here, see Rifraf Carcassonne…the River, Festivals, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, Abbey & Mayor, The Princess & the Dragon, and The Tower, Under the Big Top and Hills and Sheep, in my other posts, over 240 Tiles total.
The Original Set: 72 Tiles
The River: 12 Tiles
Festivals: 10 Tiles
Inns & Cathedrals: 18 Tiles
Traders & Builders: 24 Tiles
Abbey & Mayor: 18 Tiles
The Princess & the Dragon: 30 Tiles
The Tower: 18 Tiles
Under the Big Top: 20 Game Tiles
Hills and Sheep: 18 Tiles
How I printed: On a Prusa i3 MK2 in all PLA with a base height of .200mm and a layer height of .150 with a 4mm nozzle. 4 Base layers and 3 top layers, 15% Cubic infill with a CONCENTRIC Top/Bottom fill pattern, This is important if you want the same layer divisions and “style”. I printed with a 3mm brim attached to all tiles, I found if I did not I got the occasional corner lift, but it did mean I had to trim the sides of all the tiles.
What I painted: The tops of the farm and city houses..RED, the 6 Volcano and 6 “portal” tiles from The Princess and the Dragon…GREY, and the filled in the garden squares using a toothpick and 4 different paints for the flowers…and the tops of the festival tents…That’s it…(there are 2 tiles in The Princess & Dragon that have the cloisters AND emblems, you will have to decide between painting the cloister or wall top towers)..that is if you print the way I did.
Some issues and tips: This is very important…When slicing in Slic3r sometimes the tiles would not render with the correct number of top layers, for example the roads would only have a layer or two finished and then the fill would show through…or the fields would not have all the layers… for some reason, rotating the affected tile 90 degrees on the plate sometimes a couple times and then reslicing fixed this issue…do a good preview check to examine how your layers are printing… it was a ton of wasted prints for me to work this out.
The very base layer has the “C” cut out, if you make your base layer one color, then change to a different color for the next few layers the filament with just “flow” into this space and it looks like you have a nice inlay…it does not affect the rest of the printing in any way… this is the “poor man’s inlay trick”…also the concentric fill pattern on the bottom gives it the “scattered” look sort of like the original tiles.
The fields have a darker layer under the light green, this adds to the textured look, also the City floor has a Dark brown layer followed by two copper layers for the “cobble stone” look, you can experiment with different color materials for enhance the “3d” look of these areas.
I have not printed all the Princess & the Dragon, Under the Big Top or Traders & Builders, or Hills and Sheep…I ran out of filament... .. they look good but if they are anything like the rest of the tiles I will have to go back to correct an item or two.. Please let me know.
The Towers are designed to fit snug.
My Printing and colors: (How you slice will of course change any of these) I used Prusa Color print to define the layers.
For all tiles except the ones with a Cloister, the Cathedrals, and the Abbeys
0-.35 Light Green (The Base color, will be shaded according to the subsequent layers)
.35-1.1 Blue (For the base of the ponds)
1.1-20 Skin (for the base of the roads)(May have to be 1.25-2.0)
2.0-2.3 Copper (for the underlay dark field color)
2.3-3.2 Light Green (for the fields)
3.2-3.35 Dark Brown (for the underlay of the city floor)
3.35-3.35 Copper (for the city floor)
3.65 -4.1 Pearl White (for the base of the shields and emblems)
4.1-4.55 Blue (for the shield and emblem tops)
4.55-8.15 Khaki (for the walls)
8.15---- Blue (for the wall tops and towers)

For the Cloisters: Same to start then 3.65-9.95 is Khaki and then 9.95 and on is RED
For the Cathedrals and Abbey: Same to start then 3.65-13.40 Khaki and then 13.40 and on is RED

Your choices and colors will vary according to what you deicide.. this is just what I did. Have Fun, and if it works for you please send me a "LIKE"

description.text:
DISCLAIMER:
THIS IS JUST THE BEGINNING. DON'T DOWNLOAD ANYTHING YET. IT WON'T MAKE SENSE AND IS ENTIRELY USELESS ON ITS OWN.

this will be a collection of parts i designed and tested that are required to build an XY-plane for 3D printing. here is the basic concept:

4 steppers, one in each corner of a stiff MDF/fiberboard (NOT PARTICLEBOARD OR MELAMINE) at least 15mm thick. there are 2 steppers driving each axis--one running forward and the other in the opposite direction (each axial pair is countersynchronized).

i've considered just about every possible configuration and will post the ones that i think work best and are most versatile.

here's how they vary:
-vertically or horizontally mounted steppers
-above plane or below plane
-right-side up or upside down
-inside rails or outside rails
-aluminum tubing rails + PLA bearings or standard 8mm smooth rod + LM8LUU
-single spanners or dual spanning rods/rails for the "crosshair"
-moving bed or moving hot end (requires optional cut out in plane)
-V-mounted idler pins (M5 screws) can only go in from the bottom but i can offset the hole to allow it to be screwed in from the top

i even thought of using 2 planes to sandwich the steppers between but that didn't make much sense in terms of accessibility.

since my Z-axis and extruder are completely independent of the XY-plane, they will be ignored for now. my Z-axis converts between raising a stationary hot end or lowering a stationary bed with each successive printed layer. if you don't have an independent Z-axis, the XY-plane alone is useless. just a heads up.

so the main parts of the XY-plane will be:
-4 stepper mounts
-8 rail mounts
-4 linear bearings
-8 belt clips for the linear bearings
-upper and lower "crosshair" that will hold either a moving bed or moving hot end
-span mounts which connect the spanning rails/rods to the X and Y bearings

i'll post 28BYJ-48 V-mounts, L-bracker H-mounts and more pictures to clarify things.... as well as everything else you will need to build an XY-plane.

the main photo shows V-mounts and the assembly on the right is what i'm about to mount onto the 28BYJ-48 XY-plane.
The most powerful steam locomotive class produced in the UK. The seventh in the class is currently being built from scratch at the Darlington works https://www.p2steam.com

comments.text: Ok, That's great ..I will have a look...What is the purpose of when you draw a HILL tile of the drawing of a second tile and placing it face down under the hill tile... is this needed in the game and if so.. how would that work with 3D tiles?
comments.author: F1rstW0rd

comments.text:
The purpose of the second tile under the original is:
1) To highlight the tile as the hill effect is applied to all features (town, road, grass) on the tile. So a meeple in the town (on the hill tile) wins the tie with another meeple in the same town (another tile) even though the hill is drawn on the grass of the hill tile.
2) To remove a random tile from the game without anyone knowing what it is. From my experience, this is not necessary but when playing with intermediate players it provides a bit more fun and randomness.
In order to deal with the first, I'm thinking simply a thicker bottom or making the hole tile more dome-shaped. The second part can either just be ignored, or remove one without looking and putting it aside. It is possible to build a compartment under the hill tiles but I think its more work than what is gained.
comments.author: Srifraf

comments.text: Great work on the tokens... I used the Wolf one...however the sheep token when I slice them did not work to print on my printer...the outline is too fine for printing... I found I have to fill in the raised areas to get it to work... Attached are two tiles and some sheep and the wolf (I removed the back "ring" art on the tiles only because it seems in the original to be blank)..one tile with a vineyard and one with a hill... have a look and let me know if you think this concept will work?
comments.author: F1rstW0rd

comments.text:
These are really nice!!! The back ring was from the tokens in Under the big top, I just reused them. If they weren't there originally I agree to remove them. author: danielreichegger

description.text: This thing that happens to look like a large toilet paper roll holder is actually a large plastic wrap dispenser I've made for my wife! Just place your container/plate on the cutting board, pull the cellophane over and tear.  It is sized to work for BJ's Wholesale Club's store brand 3000 feet by 12 inch roll.

You will need a few parts in addition to the 3D printed pieces.
1.) 1x large platform to act as your base that is at least 20 inches wide, and is thick enough to inset the mounting bolts. Mine is a cutting board approximately 20in x 15in x .6in 2.) 8x 5/16th in bolts with matching nuts to mount the brackets, the holes were sized at about 8mm so the bolts I used were 5/16th which is slightly smaller. Pick your length based on the thickness of your board and bracket, keeping in mind you will need to inset the bolt into the bottom of your base unless you want them to stick out as feet. 3.) 2x 5/16th x 1.75 in Linch pins to hold the bearings on, note the end is shaped like a D. Print the parts:
2 x brackets: print them bolt holes down with support. The only place support is used is the linch pin hole.
2 x gear bearings: print them just as you would Emmets gear bearing, but flange down.
I polished my ABS printed brackets (not the bearings) in an acetone vapor bath, this is optional. Assemble:
1) Mount the brackets to your base spaced to fit your roll of plastic wrap (this will involve measuring and drilling holes), keep in mind there is some added thickness for the gear bearings which is approximately 6.5 mm (3.25 mm for each bearing). The mounting holes are slotted to make getting the spacing a bit easier. This is also where you would make insets so that the bolt heads do not protrude from the bottom of your base. 2.) Slide bearings into the end of the roll, hold the whole roll with bearings in place with one hand and slide the linch pins in to retain it. Be careful not to let one pin hold the entire weight of the roll, with leverage it could damage your bracket. This is also why I did not make the gear bearing a form fit to the linch pin.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bjiWblQ9wc0

A 3D printable rocket designed to work with the Make: Compressed Air Rocket kit. http://makeprojects.com/Project/Compressed-Air-Rocket/585/1#.UAxRPzGe5sE
Printed in two pieces from PLA on an Ultimaker, these rocket look great, and might work great... OR MIGHT EXPLODE. One lasted for three successful launches before breaking into two pieces on landing. The other two shattered on launch. Oh, the Humanity!
Photo & Videos: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbonsig/sets/72157630700622384/

• Make a compressed air rocket launcher!! See description for a link.
  • Improve the design! Native Solidworks 2012 files attached, along with a PDF drawing.
  • Slice and print. I used Cura 12.07 with default settings. 0.2mm slice height. 190 degrees. The base uses the full height of the Ultimaker, so it might have to be adjusted for a different printer. Printed in a vertical orientation, though the thumbnails here show it horizontal.
  • Clean up print if necessary. These were pretty clean for me, but I used a dremel to clean up any little overhanging materials at the top and bottom that would create interference on assembly or on the launcher.
  • Assemble the top and bottom. I heated up the bottom of the top piece to soften it a bit, and applied some cyanoacrylate glue to the top of the bottom piece, then slid them together.
  • Prepare for launch! I pumped up the chamber to 80 psi.
  • Stand back!
  • Fire!
  • Admire flight, and/or collect shattered pieces for forensic study!
    Possible improvements:
    a. I would be interested to know if ABS is any more durable than PLA. Calling all Makerbotters and Reprappers!
    b. Solidify the nosecone a bit. On my one successful rocket, the tip busted open to a ~4mm hole after the first flight.
    c. Open up the inner diameter a bit? Its a bit tight on the 1/2" Schedule 40 launch pipe. Maybe if it was opened up a bit, more energy would go in the vertical direction rather than toward explosive destruction.
    Photo & Videos: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbonsig/sets/72157630700622384/

title: Monoprice Select Mini V2. Dual Fan Mount.

description.text:
This is a dual fan hot end mount that replaces one piece of the original V2 hot end mount. You can use the original 30mm fan to cool the hot end and a standard 50mm radial (5015) for part cooling. I have included versions for the original V6 clone, one for a legit E3D V6, as well as one for an legit E3D V6 + an E3D Volcano heater block. The nozzle for the part cooling fan is very close to the heater block so it will need to be printed from ABS.

The V6 model in the STEP file is https://grabcad.com/library/e3d-v6-1-75-hotend-1 by Joseph Rafferty. The Radial fan model is https://grabcad.com/library/radial-cooling-5015-fan-50mm-dc12v-1 by Aleksandr Ivanov. The 30mm fan model is https://grabcad.com/library/30mm-fan-1 by Mitch Pricer.

comments.text: You wouldn't happen to want to share the source file?  I'd like to modify it to work with a 40mm fan.

comments.text: Yes, you would use the 'Dual_Fan_Mount_Stock.stl' file if you are using the stock hot end.
comments.author: XRT9

comments.text: Thank you! also what does everyone do to hook up the radial fan, power it inline with the other one or directly connect to psu
comments.author: lowfat

comments.text: It depends on your board. I'm hearing that some some firmware versions of the stock board will always run the fan at full speed once the hot end reaches a certain temperature. Try sending a 'M106 S1' to your printer and heat up the hot end. If the fan stays off then good. In that case you woulduse the radial fan on the fan header on the board and run the hot end cooling fan right off the power supply. Add 'M106 S1' to your starting GCODE. Then just have your slicer turn the part cooling fan on / off if necessary. If the printer turns the fan back on then unfortunately you'll just need to wire the radial fan to a switch and manually turn it on/off as needed.

comments.text: You could set the hot end fan to run off w/ the control board fan. Then use the part cooling fan w/ the existing fan wiring. You'll need to set 'M106 S1' in your starting GCODE so the part cooling fan doesn't run all the time. If you are printing PLA or whatever, just have it turn on layer 2 as you normally would.

title: Polygonal holder for Ledger Nano S or similarly sized objects

description.text:
This is for items like USB drives or the Ledger Nano S that are less than 20mm x 10mm in footprint. I designed this to hold the Ledger Nano S and give it a good futuristic look. I wanted to make it look like I was pulling out something important and special so I made a simple icosahedron holder for my Ledger Nano S, and made it just tall enough so the O ring stands out. A little centerpiece for my desktop.

What's really special about the shape is that it can be printed without any infill and doesn't need any supports because this is a hardened polygonal shape that supports itself (you'll see as it prints). The end result is a rather strong object too despite being hollow.

title: Epic Scale Modular Structure Terrain Components

description.text:
yhay, worked in STCs!! what a dork...

this is a blatant rip off of someone else's idea (as per 'components' pic). i saw a couple of pics (shown) and went nuts making variations, plus roofs etc.

with these slabs you can make countless variations from suburban themed, to industrial, to ecclesiastic, dremmel the carp out of them to make ruins or even make space ships... yes you can.

The slabs come in four prefixes (L) which are the 'large/standard' slabs, (H) for 'half-size', either vertically half or horizontally, (F) for fillers, and (R) for roof.

print, superglue, push together into flat panels, connect as required. i usually smear on some fine grade wall plaster (then sand) to hide some of the joins and also use 'texture paint' to help conceal the print striations (plus adds texture). flat roof = mdf.

i've printed a table's worth and much prefer fighting over an active settlement rather than worthless ruins. personal taste.
am planning on adding extra pipes, buttresses and gribbles eventually but they work just as well as nice plain terrain (good for clumsy fingers). and of course this site had lots of columns, statues etc that can be rescaled for nice points of interest.

my local hardware store sells 'hobby coasters' which are extra-compressed mdf and work great as standard sized bases (for those of us incapable of cutting a straight line).

i recall that some of the slabs may be missing faces from the stl conversion process. i'll try to review them all to make sure they're good to go.

description.text:
This is an extensive set of 14 lava tiles at 2x2 inches. Two tiles are only volcanic rocks. The remaining 12 are various designs with lava flowing about volcanic rock. You can create a pond or flowing rivers or just a volcanic rock environment. But wait there is more, as the commercial goes. Not only are there 14 designs with openlock connections, all 14 designs have an option of a flat base that I call a top cap. This means you can place the 14 designs on top of your own bases. The top caps can be increased in size by 125% and then be used on true tiles "Wyloch" bases as well. None of the 14 are mirrored so this would give you an additional 14 designs that are somewhat different.

comments.text: I am aware of this. When I go to pry the pieces off the plate, I can get the piece to split in two. If I don't have the pieces sticking hard, I get lift off at the corners. Even when I have resolved this problem, if I repeatedly use the clips the piece has split. I prefer the structure in the middle be there, over being able to use the middle with more versatility. If someone prefers the other connectors, they can print off the top caps and place them on the other connectors and use super glue. That's why I have the top caps as an option as well. I imagine that if someone really wanted that versatility and a single part, they could easily use one of several free programs and complete it in about 7 minutes a piece.

title: Replicator Cover Hanger Bolt Spacers v2

description.text:
A pair of spacers for drandolph's "3mm hood and cover" thingiverse.com/thing:23386 These pieces keep compression on both bolts holding the y-axis rods when hanging the front cover. I found the original were too close together and printed as one piece (probably my HBP to nozzle height). They also weren't high enough. I enlarged the center hole by .35mm as well. Inside diameter - 3.35mm
Outside diameter - 4.35mm
Height - 5.5mm
"Washer" - 8mm x .75mm The height allows for about 1mm or so of movement on the front hood, making removing/adding it a breeze. In my quest to eliminate the vibration sounds. I've added a shorter spacer set with a height of 4.5mm. The cover fits nice and snug and in combination with the lift handles & stabilizer brackets the vibration sounds are gone! For the lift handles & stabilizer brackets please see thingiverse.com/thing:27532

Printed using .27 layer height, 100% infill (solid), 1 shell. Using Replicator 5.5 but with default speeds (printing small objects like this with acceleration I find melts the previous layer too much). Printed without a raft After printing I used a .116" drill bit to open the hole slightly where it sits on the HBP. Original Tinkercad objects:
https://tinkercad.com/things/3PwNbTgAXxW-replicator-cover-hanger-bolt-spacers-v2 Shorter spacers:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0k5azjdWbEG-replicator-cover-hanger-bolt-spacers-v3-shorter

author: Calabrone

description.text:
Bracket to lower the overall height of the Anet A2. This bracket lowers the top end from 18-1/4" to 17 3/8".

I built an enclosure originally for my Anet A8 printer and the total height was 18-1/8" (Anet A8 is 17-7/8" tall). I decided to change it up and put my anet A2 in there. I knew I would have to take off the LCD panel and relocate it, but when I when to put it in there it was apparent very fast it wasn't going to fit. The over height of the A2 is 18-1/4" I found this support bracket for my A2 and had an idea, It worked out great. I didn't lose very much print height, the bottom of the coupling is almost at the same height as the bottom of the metal corner supports. I did 2 styles: one that has a support and one that does not. My plan was to use the one with the support for the Z-axis rod and the one without the support to mount the extruder. This was modified from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2193222

Also multilple 3mm holes to use the t-nuts to mount it.

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The rods in the large opening are used in [lace of supports, and come right out with very little clean up. I used Carbon Fiber PLA, so this shouldn't wear out any time soon.

I did the following fills:

side - 2mm
Top - 1mm
