title: XL-RCM 10.0 PIXXY: Pocket drone / FPV quad

description.text:
The smallest 3D printed FPV/ miniature personal nano UAV platform: XL-RCM 10.0 PIXXY : Pocket drone/FPV quad
It is consider the smallest "3D printed" FPV/UAV platform ever made for public/civilian use on the day it was released to the public on 15th March 2014. Extremely light weighted at 40 gram, palm/pocket sized, easily stored into any storage, cheaper building cost, easier to build with simple soldering skills and parts widely available in common online hobby and toy shop. I design this kit to enable me to enjoy fun indoor remote video wireless FPV flight flying through various narrow obstacles and also can be flown outdoor like its bigger brother too. The size, weight and micro rotor added safety factor minimized any harm to both living things and property should it bump into anyone or crashed into other's property.
This kit accept common and popular nano sized multirotor and FPV hardware that can be found on any hobby stores, security hardware shops and also popular online electronics supplier with building cost below USD $100 for complete personal FPV/UAV experience on normal screen/tv, all thanks to cheap open source electronics.
This 3d printed kit consist of 3x parts: the top cover, the main frame and the lower motor base cup. Required or recomended to be 3D print using plastic ABS material for rigid struture. Once done printing user only need to shed off support material and snap in all the required electronic hardware by hand. Theres no screws or glue needed to snap in all the electronics hardwares however soldering are needed to connect wires between motors, flight board controller, video transmitter and camera only. Glue only required or optional to keep the top frame cover in place if necessary.
For more details and instruction check it at this url:
http://www.supermotoxl.com/Real-object-design-for-hobby-models/3D-printed-real-object-design-for-hobby-models/xl-rcm-100-pixxy-pocket-dronefpv-quad/menu-id-118.html
Here's youtube video of "PIXXY" in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=no_pA4Xu5co
  • Do take note i'm using Z-modeler to build this 3D parts so would look "cracky" on some 3d viewer but no problem during 3D printing.
    Editable 3ds file also available at my website for those who wanted to customized/modify the kit meshes.
    • Updates: 21 Oct 2014
    **I've already include diagram of electronic hardware installation. Please check for those who are new into FPV installation.

comments.text:
I stripped the parts from this: amazon.com/gp/product/B0095BXACK/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=B0095BXACK&linkCode=as2&tag=krisk-20&linkId=ZEYLR7QXAFM7QAN6
so the total cost for the initial(FPV setup was only $20-$30 for me. The nano transmitter costs around $50 and camera for it should cost between $40-$60. However if you add the FPV setup the 250 mAh battery included above(it actually comes with 2) might be a little bit to small to give you any real flight time with the extra power consumption. So, finding a battery larger than 250 mAh and smaller than 350 mAh(just a guess at the cameras weight limits) would probably be another $10-$20. So if you are patient and spend enough time hunting down the lowest prices on these parts you could probably build the whole thing for around $110-$120 if you are lucky.
PS: if you buy the quad in the link above you have to rotate the flight board 45 degrees in the frame, which is a bit tough to do, but it won't flight without it. Also, you may have trouble connecting quad to controller: do this buy plugging battery into quad, turning remote on, then put the quad on a level surface(make sure the print is not warped or you will have to adjust so that the props are what are level), then push the the throttle up and down on the remote until it beeps and they are connected.
Good luck!
comments.author: BradStaff

extwo2
comments.author: loganj13

comments.text: So on the one I bought off of amazon, it is oriented in the way that an arm is protruding outwards perpendicularly from the middle of each side of the flightboard, and must be oriented in that way to fly. The design of the print is made for the flight board and arms to be oriented so that  the arms protrude outwards from the corners of the flightboard. This does not seem like a big deal but it must be oriented correctly to fly because it is the way the board is calibrated, so, if you mounted it to the prints intended directions, when it dips forward, a whole side of the board is dipping forwards, vs the way it is calibrated, assuming that only a corner would dip forward. So, if mounted to the design's intended orientations, when the board dips exactly forward; which I'll call north, in flight, the board "thinks" it is dipping exactly Northeast, or 45 degrees to the right in flight, and tries to level accordingly. This makes it unflyable. Luckily I've found that with some pressure, a bit of carving and sanding, you can fit the whole board from amazon below its designated area, oriented correctly. However this does not make it very exact, and even if you do managed to wedge it in at precisely 45 degrees off, any bumps may push it out. Modifying the file is  something I have yet to get around to but may sooner or later. I hope this helped!

comments.author: letroll

comments.text: Not possible because at its current size it can only use nano CCTV derived analog video technology. Adding extra small HD camera such as smallest HD keychain camera as secondary recording option will prohibit its ability to lift the load due to its small size. Only quad sized 160mmx160mm such as "V929" models could carry euipment load that have higher resolution such as this one in the link: http://www.supermotoxl.com/FPV/UAV-models-builds-and-flight-reviews/FPV/UAV-models-builds-and-flight-reviews/v929-mini-drone-160mm/menu-id-119.html

How to customize the words on the caps in fusion 360

1st: load up file in Fusion 360
2nd: under sketches click light bulb beside sketch 4 and 5
3rd: right click the sketch Evan then left click edit sketch
4th: then right click Evan and left click edit text
5th: change text to what you want and size depending on how big your item is
6th: press enter
7th: repeat steps 1-6 for Hudson
I used Fusion 360. I'm new to the software. I used Solidworks before this.

description.text:
Welcome new followers and transplants from the TRAV 2.0 build. The build was branched to this 2.1 version due to all of the design changes. The new chassis is more detailed and has a smaller foot print. All of the suspension parts has been changed also.

Background:

I built the original Trav (Terra Roving Autonomous Vehicle) back in 2015. It was built on an a hobby grade rc electric 4x4 truck.

Goal:

The goal is to not only have a functional rover, but to make it strong enough to go crawling with my buds. This is proving to be more difficult than first thought because of the known abuse the crawlers take and the diverse terrain they drive in. This is from mud to water to rock crawling and everything in between.

Trav 2.1 will have autonomous with obstacle avoidance as well as human control capabilities with planned GPS support as well. It is designed around the NASA Curiosity Rover (minus the MMRTG power plant of course :) ) It will have independent 6 wheel drive and 4 wheel steering. 3 steering modes and the rocker bogie suspension. 3S battery will power Trav.

Build Status 1-8-2018
I uploaded the rest of the stl files. I will not be updating any of the files for a while. They work for me. Enjoy it and make it your own!

Build Status 12-19-2017 b.
I uploaded a picture of the older v2.0 suspension to illustrate the size. It is a bit larger than the Rally car, however, it is still around the same size of a 1/10 scale crawler.

The following was brought over from the TRAV 2.0 build. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2663155

Build Status 12-19-2017
I am still waiting on my new hotbed. In the meantime, I have almost finished the new design. I have decided to branch it out as TRAV 2.1 due to all of the changes. I have redesigned almost everything. I decided that I didn't like the rounded edges as much and I also reduced the bulkiness of the suspension parts. I posted more parts for this build, but, remember that I am abandoning it. Consider them as freebies. :) I hope to see you all over at the new build. I will post a link to it shortly.

Build Status 12-15-2017
The build is hold for the moment. A sensor wire came off of my hotbed, so I am going to go ahead and put the larger bed on it. I think I am going to change the design of the chassis. The main reason is a design flaw. The problem is that it takes days to print the front and rear chassis sections. The second reason is that I am not 100% sold on the looks. I started working on a new chassis design that takes much less time to print and looks better according to a few people that I have asked. I added the picture as a sneak peek. I will most likely also tweak the suspension parts to match the design.

Carbon Fiber Tube x2
Size: OD 20Mm X ID 18Mm X L 500Mm

6x10x3 Flanged Bearings x4 for the upper bogie joint that connects to the chassis. These fit in to the chassis side. I used these because that was what I had.

5x10x4 Bearings x4 for the lower bogie joint that attaches both tires and has the shock mount.

16GA Wire for Motors
65mm Shock Absorbers x2
130mm Shock Absorbers x2
Hobbywing 1040 60A Waterproof Brushed ESC x2
MG996R Servo's x5
12vdc 300rpm Motor x6
https://www.ebay.com/itm/12V-DC-3-5RPM-300RPM-Torque-Magnetic-Mini-Electric-Motor-for-DIY-Toys-Cars-SA1/222679745925?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=521534402905&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

4mm to 12mm hex Shaft Coupler
https://www.ebay.com/itm/3-4-5-6-7-8-mm-Brass-Shaft-Couplings-Coupler-Motor-12MM-Hex-connector-DIY-Screws/181739759207?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=480686801263&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

Servo Mount and Servo Shaft from Servocity

m3 x 30mm, lock nuts x2 - Shock Clips
m6 x 100mm, washers, lock nuts x2 - Upper Bogie Joint
m5 x 65mm, washers, lock nuts x2 - Lower Bogie Joint
m4 x 14mm, washers x6 - Wheels
m3 x 6mm x4 - Servo
m3 x 40mm, lock nuts x16 - Servo Joints

6 - 32 x 3/8" x16 - Servo Mounts - Servocity
6 - 32 x 3/8" x16 - Servo Shaft - Servocity
m3 x 25mm, washers, lock nuts x6 - Motor Mounts
m3 x 25mm, lock nuts x6 - Servo Coupling to Motor Mount
m3 x 15mm, lock nuts x8 - Servo Bearing Retainer
m3 x 35mm, lock nuts x16 - Carbon Tubes to Mounts
m2.5 x20mm, washers, lock nuts x4 - Shock Mounts

1) The bearing retainer must be installed in the correct rotation. It is not bidirectional.
2) Almost all of the suspension parts have a left and right version.
3) The 130mm shocks only have a few drops of oil in them in order to lubricate the O rings. The only function for them is to stop the lower bogie system from spinning around too much.

description.text:
This is mainly just a scaled version of the beautiful X-Wing model created by ToolBox3D (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1212999). I just scaled it down to the size I needed and put a loop on top.

The other quasi source I pulled from was the excellent Tie Interceptor ornament created by Goubeauxr (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1955227). Nothing was taken from this model but I wanted to make it's partner in crime.

I printed my Tie Interceptor at 100 mm in length (about). I wanted the X-Wing to be correctly scaled when compared to the Tie Interceptor. They'd look silly chasing each other around the Christmas tree if they were disproportionate.

According to Google, the length of each ship is as follows:

Tie Interceptor: 31' (9.6 m)
X-Wing: 41' (12.5 m)

I printed my Tie Interceptor with a length of 100 mm. The X-Wing is supposed to be about 133% the length of the Interceptor (or about 1/3 longer). I scaled these models so that, when combined and facing forward, it ended up being about 132 mm long.

Please keep in mind that I have this queued up as my next print but I haven't actually made it yet. I'm matching it to the same settings I used for the Tie Interceptor. Once it's all printed, I'll post a picture.

P.S.: I threw in my factory file in case anyone else is a Simplify3D fan and wants to print in Hatchbox Wood PLA. Please, though, keep in mind it's for Wood PLA. You wouldn't need this sort of retraction/lift/etc with regular PLA.

Update #1: Added an STL and factory file for those who want to print this as one single piece. This is how I'm opting to print it.

Update #2: I went a little further and added a supported version I created using MeshMixer. I recommend trying this one first if you have a large enough print bed. Mine is almost done printing but, from what I can see via OctoPrint, it's worked wonderfully.

Sidenote: I'm thrilled by how much people seem to be enjoying this model. I just want to stress again that I'm just plagiarizing someone else's amazing modeling work : )

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You can probably go lower on the infill. I'm using Hatchbox Wood PLA and I know that, at this size, the weight should be pretty good.

Protip for Hatchbox Wood PLA: Use lots of retraction but, first and foremost, find a temp that works for you. I've heard people say to use 220 and others suggest 183. 220 for me burns and 183 just isn't hot enough and clogs. For me, 192 is the sweat spot but it may be completely different for you.

I recommend this. Get your hotend up to 185 and manually feed the filament to feel what flow rate you get. Then bump up the heat by 3 and go again. Keep going until the flow seems to have maxed and then dial it back a step (so it's not magma). Seriously, this is how everyone should dial in all types of filament when they open a package. Just my opinion.

A pan-tilt mechanism for use in a project my friend is working on (it involves lasers). I made liberal use of the MCAD library (involute_gears.scad only, plus its dependencies). This is my first model made using OpenSCAD, so be gentle ;P.

comments.text:
It is a nice design but I think you would have a cleaner print if you split each of the two larger parts in half, so they could be printed without needing support. Then, it would be good to have either snap features, or screws for re-assembly, as just gluing parts is often tricky to align and sometimes not as strong. Thinking about it, I'm tempted to put rollers in for smoother tilt action.
It is interesting to me that after 2 years and over 1000 downloads, no one has shown a picture of an actual print of this thing, or even commented. Has anyone made one that works?

description.text:
Specific to the stand (Walmart-Mainstays if I recall?) shown in the images, or wire shelving with 30mm on center wire spacing, these snap on accessories provide a toothbrush holder and a simple tablet/phone stand.
They snap over the shelf wires and stay firmly in place.
It is easiest to snap them on in the center of the shelf wire away from the perpendicular support rods where there is some extra give, then slide easily to either side to desired position.

I believe this is the unit I had purchased:
https://www.walmart.com/ip/Mainstays-3-Shelf-Bathroom-Space-Saver-Satin-Nickel-Finish/24775812

This is one of my first tests on my new 3D printer (CR 10S). The boat main part was printed as one piece with a height of ~ 390 mm.
The print settings of the body can be found in the txt file.
The motors, transmitter and receiver were taken from an old BIG-one Helicopter.
I printed the flat cover only.
I used PLA filament for all parts except the sealing which was printed using FlexPLA filament.

I used 20% fill for the boat body and 100% for the propeller and sealing

If you have any enquiries, I will be happy to answer you.
If you have a suggestion of other practical components of this design, I may do them.

Enjoy the Thing!

You can print now more coding blocks for your cubetto playset (the one from Primotoys). Each coding block has the correct number and placement of holes on its back. So just put in magnets (3mm length, 2mm diameter) and use some glue so they stay in.

The coding blocks which come with the cubetto (forward, left, right, function) are included. Also the special ones (backward, negation, random) which are only included in the kickstarter campaign are included. I was lacking the latter, couldnt order them, so i designed this replacement.

To get the correct color, you could either print each coding block in the correct color (see https://www.primotoys.com/ as a reference) or stick coloured paper on top of each block.

If you like the tiles, also look into my configurable text based creations, e.g. name plate, Customizable text box with lid, round text and sweeping name plate. And look at my configurable pack of dogs and rabbits.

Please post your makes as "i made one"! I am curious what my customizable designs are used for and wether printing works out well. Also if you have ideas or wishes, let me know.

Have fun!

UPDATES:
V2 - Nose shortened slightly, RunCam HD Bay reduced in size for more snug fit, cover adjusted to suit the new camera bay size, dimples on the back surface removed.

This is an extended nose section for the Mini Drak flying wing. It involves chopping the nose off of the mini drak foam fuselage and gluing this replacement on.

The replacement is extended by 20mm from the original length of the nose, to fully accommodate a RunCam HD 2 camera and also an HS1177 camera. This is a single piece nose with a slide in cover for the HD cam.

Designed to be printed nose pointing up, flat base on the print bed. Chamfers added to most of the design to avoid horizontal overhangs.

Please feel free to test and feedback any findings.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a simple mold i created to produce a small batch of candles as a christmas present.
The candle it produces is also uploaded as an stl file.

I printed the mold halves in ABS with 10% Infill and 0.28mm layer height. It came out pretty well but you will probably experience some hairline cracking after first filling it with hot wax. I simply patched those with cyanoacrelate and baking soda - which is a good trick to know if you make any kind of low temperature molds.

The risers in the mold are not strictly necessary but i included them anyway, as they help to prevent overflowing while filling.

Now how to use it:
I first sanded the mating surfaces and then rubbed a little beeswax on them to make them smooth. The halves are then clamped together using any type of woodworking clamp. The pre-waxed wick can then be inserted through the top and through the little hole in the bottom. It can then be folded over or tucked under one of the clamps to prevent it coming loose.

Before you pour in your wax make sure it is not hotter than about 70°C (or as hot as 13 turtle bezoars for those using different measurement systems).

After pouring it is important to keep a little tension on the wick so it stays in the center of the candle, I simply clamped it between to pencils wrapped with a rubber band.

Leave enough time for the mold to cool down, 3D prints with little infill are quite effective insulators, at room-temperature it will take upwards of an hour, but you can drastically accelerate cooldown by submerging it in a sink filled with cold water.

If the mold is cooled down enough seperation should be easy as candle wax shrinks a lot.

As always - Have fun and I am not liable if you burn yourself or make a mess in your kitchen!

ENGLISH
Update for MGRIP Project
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2704775

The objetive for this module is to give L1, L2, R1 & R2 buttons in the classic gamepad layout, for more confortable usage for the GPD-Win device.

This is a first version, focussed on get a working grip module.
The size of the grip is slighty bigger than expected (compared with Dualshock/PS3 controller), and i hope to get another version with a condensed design.

The module have the following features (check the design images for references https://goo.gl/4gdGHf):

  • There is a small piece that ensure some distance between the grip mechanism and the GPD-Win. This piece is for regulation of the grip. If you need the mechanism (white) more near to the device, simply use sandpaper for lowering this piece (red piece on the images)
  • There are two cubes (green). These cubes are for helping to put the face buttons. You must adjust/press the facebutton, using these cubes for avoid breack the mechanism (orange pieces). use your thumb finger for give support when installing facebuttons.
  • Facebuttons may be printed in different color.

Hope you found useful!

ESPAÑOL
Actualización para el proyecto MGRIP
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2704775

El objetivo de este módulo es proporcionar los botones L1, L2, R1 y R2 en la posición clásica de un gamepad, para un uso mas cómodo del dispositivo GPD-Win

Esta es una primera versión, enfocada a obtener un módulo de grip funcional.

El tamaño del grip es ligeramente mas grande de lo esperado (comparado con un Dualshock 3/X360 controller), y espero desarrollar otra versión con un diseño mas "condensado"

El módulo tiene las siguientes características (Revisa las imágenes de diseño para referencia https://goo.gl/4gdGHf)

  • Existe una pequeña pieza (roja en los dibujos) que asegura una idstancia entre el mecanismo del Grip (Blanco) y el dispositivo. Si necesitas ajustar el grip, acercando el mecanismo al botón del dispositivo, simplemente lija esta pieza hasta encontrar la distancia adecuada
  • Existen 2 cubos (verdes). Estos cubos son para ayduar a instalar las caretas de los botones. Para ello, debes poner el dedo en este cubo y por el otro lado instalar la careta, evitando hacer demasiado esfuerzo que podría romper el mecanismo (piezas de color anaranjado).
  • Las caretas de los botones se pueden imprimir en distintos colores.

Espero encuentres interesante y útil este Módulo!

title: For the Love of Oregon Refrigerator Magnets

description.text:
EDIT: I have included 6mm x 3mm indents for these: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B074T9FDCK

I added four 10mm x 2mm indents for extra magnets I had from on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0714KZP5C

Having the magnets flush with the print surface allows the object to hold paper on the whole surface while being a lot stronger than covering it with magnet strips.

I recommend using cheaper magnets since four 10x2 is probably overkill.

A STEP file is included to easily make changes.

author: dangiemanz

print_settings.Notes:: With a brim of 15mm I have printed a 250mm length of 2020 in PETG without any issues. With a 5mm brim the 2020 separated at around 100mm high.

description.text:
I put this together as a test after seeing a few people printing their own profiles and wanted to give a few different profiles a go for myself.

As it stands you can produce your own customizer .stl files by choosing the profile type (currently 2020, 2040 or 2080) and then the length of the profile you want.

I've also used this as a basis to build profiles with built in brackets for 45 degree and 90 degree connections. I'm still playing with the design of those though and will add them as an option later if anyone's interested in this design.

The design of the profile is an amalgamation of measurements from a number of specification diagrams and some of the measurements may well get tweaked as I use the profiles created and test them.

I've tried printing with different materials and layer heights and also tried printing vertically as it comes and also with the profile laid on it's side. Printing vertically tends to be neater but can lead to issues as the lengths increase ! I'll update the printing section as I decide what works the best.

Version history...
v1.0 First version with 2020 and 2040 profiles
V1.0.1 Added 2080 profile
v1.0.2 Made the slot size customisable and changed the default to 6mm (was 5mm) stl files also updated to 6mm

Notes:

Ideally you probably want to print this vertically as it gives the best quality without using any supports. You'll need to use a large brim, especially when printing over 100mm, to support the "tower" as it prints because the taller you go the more stress on the bed adhesion.

With a brim of 15mm I have printed a 250mm length of 2020 in PETG without any issues. With a 5mm brim the 2020 separated at around 100mm high.

remixed_from.author: lord_alan
remixed_from.title: Yet Another Mosfet mount for the Anet A8

title: SIMPZIA Mosfet Mount For ANET A8 Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I started with a Thing from user lord_alan. I loaded his original design file in OpenSCAD and adjusted it for the SIMPZIA Mosfet I bought online (got a 2 pack for a good price, with all the extra wires and crimps I'd need along with it). This is my first remix of a part, so if I missed some courtesy or committed some other fopaux please forgive me.

I found one Thing that is a main board frame that is spaced for this module, but it was only half complete (no vent holes or cable openings). On a suggestion in the A8 group on FB, I modded this Thing to fit this module, and since the power and heat bed connections are on opposite sides, I flipped the mount so the module sits sideways under (or over I suppose if you wanted) to make wiring a bit easier/neater.

UPDATE 1/1/2018:
On a request I reworked the SCAD file to change from a landscape to portrait layout, and added that file. Also on request I modded both versions to add a mount for a second MOSFET board. I'm not sure how well it would fit with 2 on their honestly, and I didn't want to change the spacing between the controller and MOSFET's too much otherwise wires are going to get in the way of each other. If you want to use two MOSFET's on your machine, I suggest printing two single mount frames, and mount one below the control board in landscape orientation for the heat bed, and a the second on a separate frame in portrait orientation above the control board for the hot end. The wires from each item should reach a little better that way.

Looking at the dual mount frame, it should fit, though it might be a little tight depending on how/where you ran the wires in your A8 build.

Some of these are a bit rough. I'll only say I'm not a CAD guy, I haven't done any 3D modeling in about 20 years, so I just do what I can to muddle through.

ANET A8

No

No

description.text:
This is a fix for the belt squeal issue on the Y axis of an RB2.

Since the design has no belt tension-er it is hard to get the belts to line up on the pulleys such that they do not ride up and rub on the belt guards causing an annoying squeaking noise. One solution is to purchase a flanged bearing and cut out the belt guards. This solution is a 3D printable one.

The tapered part (with an M3 x 14mm bolt threaded part way in) is inserted into the square open area under the bearing on the front plate of base and while pinching the bearing post and the front panel with pliers tap it in till the belt rides on the center of the bearing.

Use thermally calibrated filament to get the best fit. The interlocking clip method works really well for calibration.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:250267
or
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301

Printer:

RBB3 XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

24%

Notes:

This is a very small part. Use a 1.2mm wall, top, and bottom thickness and a 10 line brim to help the part stay put.

Clean-up

Remove the brim and thread in an M3 x 14mm bolt about 5mm. This gives you something to tap on to drive it into the slot.

A very simple belt anchoring system centered around a belt clip design I originally came across by Area51.

I've include clips for both the standard ANET-A8 belt that comes with the kit and another which fit standard GT2 belts.

In version 2 of the clips, I've expanded on the original design by adding a slot to hold a little extra length of belt in the case that you need to make it a bit longer in the future.

I've also included some extremely simple X and Y Carriage mounts for the ANET-A8. The the Y anchor was designed for a belt attachment point which is ~12mm lower than the base of the carriage (with the 'H' crossbar on top).

The spacer is there in case you need the belt attachment point a little lower.

BTW: If you use the X/Y Anchors, use a couple of M3 washers to prevent your belt from slipping off.

Cheers,
-HD

title: [Fixed] Dual 26650 vape with linear magnetic switch (print in place)

description.text:
Disclaimer

This page and the files and materials contained herein are for educational purposes only. We do not take any responsibilities for malfunctions or possible injuries or any thing happened or suffered by those who use this information. Basic electronics knowledge and common sense apply.

Updates

  • Remixed broken STL so it loads correctly
  • Flipped cover so finish matches on both sides of box.
  • Added improved momentary switch (not attached)
  • Moved atomizer post from center to end
  • Made a slim version v2
  • Revised lid for slim version for tighter fit
  • Added v2 print in place switch

Assembly

The print in place switch work against the repulsive force of 2 neodymium magnets or a small compression spring. I used these magnets which worked great. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MZ6EJE2/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
After cleaning off the switch with a hobby knife place a dot of superglue on a magnet and using a screw driver of tweezers carefully press it firmly into the socket inside of the switch assembly blowing gently until you can safely remove the screwdriver. Once after a couple of minutes once the glue has fully set, test with a second magnet to find the repulsive side and mark it with a black marker. Now place a dot of superglue on the other side of the magnet and firmly press it into the opposing side. This is the tricky part the magnet will want to flip over or move away as you insert it. you may want to use 2 tools. One to hold the magnet down and another to adjust it into position.

After you have sanded and finished the box and button you can paint or resin coat. I used an epoxy resin product called XTC-3D combined with a little black acrylic paint. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00PFXK4JY/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Once the pieces are finished, you should attach your linear switch. the button is long enough you can adjust the position to your liking. Some people may want a button that sticks out further. I Like the button to stick out just enough that when its fully pressed the button is flush with the case. Once you figure out the positioning attach the switch with a generous amount of superglue. Once this has dried you can press the button fully to see there the backstop will need to be attached making sure to leave enough extra space for your conductive contacts / momentary switch (if you are building a MOSFET switch).

You will need to figure out battery connections. either metal clips or springs should work as long as they have a large surface area. Someone suggested using sanded pennies. I also recommend using the largest gauge solid copper wire you can fit into the box. You should figure out your connections and wires and do all of the soldering first. Regardless of if you are making the series or parallel build Always make sure you have wired correctly. Once everything has been connected then fit everything into your box with hot glue.

PRO TIP: if you use hotglue and solder in any project always hotglue last. Its important to do the hotglue last as your soldering tool will heatup your wires and connections enough to melt all the hotglue into a huge sticky mess.

Batteries: Use 40A 26650's (60A is better if you can find them) Find good quality batteries. Always make sure your batteries are inserted correctly!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:
  • for the box i used .25mm 10% infill
  • for the switch use 0.1mm 50% infill w/ supports (touching buildplate)

comments.author: BSchuler

title: Tevo Little Monster Delta - Detailed Calibration Walkthrough

description.text:
*** WARNING: This is still in progress... I will continue to update and change this to say complete when done

Update: If you have not already seen / read these two posts on the Tevo Forum, you should do so now. The first is recommended steps, and given my fan has a screw falling out, its time for me to go get locktite.

  • https://tevo-3d-printers.com/viewtopic.php?f=27&t=305#p994
  • https://tevo-3d-printers.com/viewtopic.php?f=27&t=351#p995

This is a walkthrough of how I manually calibrated my Tevo Little Monster (TLM) Delta 3d Printer. I also have written up details, how to flash the firmware and hints on building the TLM here (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2721502)

I recently bought a Tevo Little Monster. After building it, I found that I could not auto calibrate the printer. Instead I ended up following the below steps to manually calibrate the 3d printer. Hopefully these instructions will help you all do the same. Did it work? Do you need help? Please leave a comment.

Updates:

  • I will add change history as updates are made
  • 1/5/18: Added new BLTouch Offset Procedure
  • 12/30/17: Added links to Tevo forum above (you should read them)
  • 12/30/17: Note about nozzle/BLTouch offset (Critical)
  • 12/27/17: Updated with successful print info
  • 12/26/17: Updated Configure Slic3r, First Print, Object 1 and Object 2
  • 12/21/17: Added more heated bed details
  • 12/21/17: Initial Add

Sorry about the multiple saves, I've lost a LOT of edits due to token timeout and this is the only way I can find to not lose my work.

You will need the following:
  • Tevo Little Monster Delta 3d Printer
  • A computer (I am using a mac)
  • The USB cable that came with your printer

For this effort, we will use "PrintRun" software from http://www.pronterface.com/.

I downloaded the "Printrun-Mac-18Nov2017.zip" file. If you have a windows machine, get the "Printrun-win-18Nov2017.zip" file.

Unzip and run the PrintRun tool. If you are on a Mac, you may have to right click the file (two finger tap) and select open.

Picture 1 is the Main user interface

The Tevo Little Monster (TLM) uses a Smoothie board clone as its controller. The PrintRun application should automatically detect your correct serial port and communications speed.

Picture 2 shows the port setting and correct connection speed

I have seen many posts where owners have had their printer go out of control, smash into the bottom end plate, smash into the top plate or more. To try and avoid causing damage, we will test printer systems slowly and carefully

Verify Basic Movement
We will start by verifying basic movement of your printer. We will use the "10" step section to verify basic motion (see image 3 above). Pay attention to where your hot end is currently located. The below assumes you are facing the front of your printer (the display should be in front of you.)

First lets test the Y axis. This will move the hot end forward and backward. Press -Y in the 10 ring to move the print head forward 10 steps. If that has worked, now press +Y in the 10 ring to move the print head back where it started.

Next test the X axis. This will move the hot end left and right. +X should move the hot end to the right. Press -X to move it back to the left.

Lastly test the Z axis. This will move the hot end up and down. Press +Z to move the gantry up. See below, I had to hit this button multiple times.

Note: For me, the system did micro steps on the Z axis. This means that every 1 step is really 1/32 of a traditional step (aka, a tiny step).

Note 2: Even when the rig is not moving, the motors will engage to hold absolute position. This can cause a high pitch squeal. To turn off the motors, press the "motors off" button in the top left or send command M84. Do not worry, as soon as you command the system to move again, it will move without having to turn the motors back on.

Optical EndStops are small LED sensors that stop the Vertical Carriages from crashing into the top of the printer. They are the small electronic boards at the top of each extrusion facing down. When you power on the printer, or plug in the USB, you should see all three sensors light up with a red light. The small screws sticking out of the top of each carriage are what triggers the sensors.

If the End Stops do not light up red, you have a bad connection or a bad sensor.

Test the End Stops
Testing the ends top

The GCode command "M119" will read out the current status of your end stops. With nothing blocking them, type M119 in the command box in the bottom right and click the "Send" button. You should get back something like

X min:0 Y min:0 Z min:0

Now test each axis by putting a coin between the two black towers. I used an extra sd card. When you place something between the two segments the light will turn off. If you now send/run the M119 command with the space blocked, you should get the below results

Left Sensor
X min:1 Y min:0 Z min:0

Right Sensor
X min:0 Y min:1 Z min:0

Back Sensor
X min:0 Y min:0 Z min:1

If all of the above have worked, home your machine by typing in G28 and hitting the "Send" button. The printer should raise the internal systems all the way to the top of the printer, check its hight 1-2 times, and stop.

The below is based off of the bottom of this document: https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/3dprintersbay/TEVOLM-TIPS-v0.7.pdf

Run the following command: (only type the text before the semi colon ";" then press the send button)

M280 S3 ; Set BLTouch to probing position (light on, pin out)

The probe should extend and a red light should turn on. Using your finger, gently press up on the probe. The probe should move up and the light will go out. Now remove your finger. The probe should drop to its original position and the light should turn back on.

Run the below to turn off the BLTouch

M280 S7

The probe should retract and the light should turn off.

If you want to reset the probe (it may be blinking since you have triggered it), run the below command.

M280 S10.6

Assuming all of the above worked, it is time to try auto calibration.

Now that all of your sensors appear to work, run the following auto calibration test. Run each of the below commands one at a time.

G28          ; Go to the Home position
M280 PS3     ; Set BLTouch to probing position (light on, pin out)
G32          ; Do a basic Z-Plane probing and calculation (9 point sections)
G31          ; Do a more complex Z-Plane probing and calculation (grid test)
M374         ; Save Calibration Grid
M500         ; Save firmware
M280 PS7     ; Set BLTouch to idle position (light off, pin in)
G28          ; Return to Home position

Possibly easier way to calibrate machine

(Updated 1/5/18)
I found an easier way to calibrate the offset if you're willing to use the direct tool. The original process is below. NOTE: I'm writing this now and will update in a few minutes.

(This is based on Redemptioner's post: section 13 in this post https://tevo-3d-printers.com/viewtopic.php?f=27&t=305#p994)

Open PronterFace/PrintRun and connect to your printer

Safely Go To a Starting Height

  • Home The Printer: In the command box at the bottom right of the window, type G28 and hit send (this will optically home the printer at the top of the chassis)
  • Extend the BLTouch Probe:
    • send "M280 S10.6" to clear BLTouch errors
    • send "M280 S3" to extend the BLTouch probe
  • Validate BLTouch: If you have not already, use the above section "Validate BLTouch Unit" to ensure your BLTouch is working correctly.
  • Find Bed and Set Offset:
    • send "G30 Z0" the print head will lower itself until the BLTouch triggers. It will then set the initial BLTouch z axis offset to 0mm. We'll fix this in a moment.
      Validate the BLTouch: follow the above "Validate BLTouch Unit" section if you have not already done so.
      Get Some Height: send "g1 z10" to raise your print head to z = 10mm
      *Go to Z = 0: send "g1 z0" to lower to the BLTouch calculated zero height

Calculate Actual Offset

  • Place a piece of thin paper on the print bed
  • Counting as you go, lower the print head .1mm at a time until the paper does not move
    • In PrintRun, (see third image above) click the "down .1mm button." This is the first white square below the center grey divider on the right hand control column.
  • When the paper does not move, move up one click (.1mm), the paper should move with friction.
    • Redemptioner recommends moving an 2 additional clicks (+.2mm) upward. You should experiment and see what works best for your prints.
  • Continue to the below without moving your print head

Save Z Probe Height Offset
Redemptioner and I save the offset in different ways.

Redemptioner recommends that you store the offset in your printer hardware using the following commands. With the print head at the new Z height send the following commands via the bottom right control in PronterFace:

  • send "M306 Z0" to set your new Z=0 height
  • send "M500" to save this into the printers firmware

Instead, I probe bed height and set the offset with every print (it takes <30 seconds). To do this, I have modified the custom start gcode in Slic3r (Printer Settings, Custom G-code section) to include the following command:

  • G30 Z1.1 ; Set GLTouch bed offset to 1.1
  • NOTE: This is one line of several in my custom start gcode

The original procedure is below.

THIS SECTION AND BELOW STILL IN DRAFT. The above is mostly correct and validated

Validate and set the offset distance between the end of the BLTouch and hot end nozzle. This is adapted from instructions here (https://tevo-3d-printers.com/viewtopic.php?f=26&t=341)

Set Initial Height
Using PronterFace / PrintRun, run the below code

Update 12/30/17: I had to again change my nozzle offset setting to 1.1. I have not yet figured out what is slipping, but will be unscrewing and reassembling with locktite. The symptom was that my extruder was slipping (clicking noise) and one side of my print was not laying down material, when the extruder was clicking. I thought it was an extruder problem, but re-calculated the offset and again it works great and happy.

Default is apparently about 2... mine was 1.41. Update: I re-ran this test to validate it, and crashed my nozzle into my base plate. Then found that my original determination of 1.7 was no longer correct. I re-calibrated the distance and now the distance is 1.41. Why is this? I have NO clue. Keep an eye on your nozzle height and maybe check it before each build by going to 10, 1, then .5? 

G28             ; Homes all axis
M280 S10.6      ; Clear BLTouch errors . After this command it should not flash
M280 S3         ; BLTouch extend probe
G1 Z55 F2500    ; Move to 50 off the bed speed 2500
G1 Z10 F250     ; Move to 10 off the bed speed 250

G30 Z0.1        ; Set a small offset between the BLTouch tip 
                ;      and where the printer thinks the nozzle ends

G1 Z10          ; Get some height (reuse last speed)
M280 S10.6      ; Clear BLTouch errors.
M280 S7         ; BLtouch retract probe
G1 Z0           ; Test the new zero (feel for slight drag with 
                ;      a sheet of paper under the nozzle)

Having sent the "G1 Z0" command, the nozzle tip will be where the machine now thinks Z0. Z0 being the nozzle at its lowest point, touching the print bed (or just above)

Use a sheet of normal printing paper to feel for resistance between the bed and nozzle.
Make sure the paper is only under the nozzle, not under the bltouch sensor when the G30 Zx.x is issued.
If you get some light drag then you have your Z offset value.
If not go on to calibration loop below (which reiterates some of the code above)

Calibration Loop (gcode to check z values until you are happy with the G30 Z offset value)

Take small steps and take your time!!! If you make the offset too large, your nozzle will crash into the bed, attempt to keep going (making a horrible noise) and you will have to turn off your printer AND remove the USB cable so that the printer reboots)

Repeat the below until...
Repeat the below until a piece of paper between the nozzle and the bed can move with resistance. In my case, the paper either was completely trapped and didn't move at all (at setting G30 Z1.8) or had no friction (G30 Z1.7). 1.75 did not appear to have any difference, but I may do some more testing. For my first print, I am going to try the no friction (1.7) offset setting and will update with more details.

G1 Z10      ; [top of loop] Get some height (reuse last speed)
M280 S10.6  ; Clear BLTouch errors
M280 S3     ; BLTouch extend probe

G30 Z0.2    ; Set Z offset value ++increase this value by .1 each loop, ie G30 Z0.3, G30 Z0.4, ...

Default is apparently about 2... mine was 1.7

G1 Z10      ; Get some height
M280 S10.6  ; Clear BLTouch errors
M280 S7     ; BLtouch retract probe
G1 Z0       ; if there is resistance on the paper after this command then we 
        ; have the final G30 Z value to go into the slic3r configuration
        ; if there is still too much space, go back to [top of loop] and try again

Initial Version

  • (based off of gcode from: http://reprap.org/wiki/Start_GCode_routines#Custom_Start_GCode)
  • using calibration calculations from (link)

Procedure below

update: I switched back to a feed of 1 (which may be too much.. I'm testing .97 next).
See first build notes section below
Mine was 111 instead of 100... my calc is 0.9009
Remove the tube from your extruder... do this by pushing in the connector while pulling out the tube. With the tube removed... run commands, measure length, write more instructions (dont do this yet)

If you've never loaded filament before.. (explain how to load filament). Also do not forget to put the bolt on the end, or your filament will fall off like mine did.

Extrude until a small amount sticks out of your printer. Mark it, extrude 10 cm. Measure actual distance. Test again, measure again, use function to calculate feed rate multiplier

G21 ;metric values
M82 ;set extruder to absolute mode
G92 E0 ;zero the extruded length
G1 E10 ; extrude 10 mm of filament
G92 E0 ; reset extruder

G92 E0 ;zero the extruded length
G1 F200 E3 ;extrude 3mm of feed stock
G92 E0 ;zero the extruded length again

G92 E0 ; Reset Extruder
G1 E-8.0 F9000 ; Retract filament

description.header: Validate Heated Bed and Hot End
description.text:
Initial Draft

Test Heated Bed
Turn on the heated bed and validate its actual versus reported temperature.
Using PrintRun, send the below command. DO NOT TOUCH THE BED, IT IS HOT!

M190 S80 ; Set Heatbed to 80 degrees C

The command window will tell the actual temperature and commanded temperature. Once the bed thinks it has reached the requested temp, use a thermometer to validate this. I used an IR thermometer, but any kitchen thermometer should work (instant read is of course faster). You will want to test in multiple place around the edge, about 2 inches in and at the center. My bed only reach 77 at the center, ~70 at 2" and was 58-65 at the edge. When done, send the below command to turn off the heated bed.

M140 S0 ; Set Bed temperature to 0 (actually turn it off)

Test Hot End
Turn on the Hot End and validate its actual versus reported temperature.
Using PrintRun, send the below command. DO NOT TOUCH THE NOZZLE (OR THE BED), IT IS HOT!

M109 S200 ; heat nozzle to 200 degC and wait until reached

The command window will tell the actual temperature and commanded temperature. Once the nozzle thinks it has reached the requested temp, use a thermometer to validate its temperature. When done, send the below command to turn off the hot end.

M104 F0 ; Set Extruder temperature to 0

Initial Version

  1. Download the latest version of Slic3r (http://slic3r.org/download). I'm using the 1.3.0-dev build.
    • I'm using a Mac, but I assume the menu layout is the same... If not, hopefully it is similar.
  2. Import the Slic3r config from the small SD Card (also attached to this thing)
    • In the "File" menu, select "Load Config" and select the config file monster_slic3r.ini. This is the originally included config that came with my printer.
    • In the "File" menu, select "Load Config Bundle" and select the config file Monster_Slic3r_config_bundle.ini. This is an export of my config options and should include all of the below updates (no promises).
  3. From the "Settings" Menu, select "Print Settings". I made the following changes:
    • This opened a new tab for me
    • In Layers and Perimeters: I set "Layer Height" to golden ratio height 0.1618
    • In Layers and Perimeters: I set "First Layer Height" to golden ratio height 0.3236
    • In Skirt and Brim: I set "Exterior Brim Width" to 0
    • When done, I clicked the save icon in the top right, next to the drop down.
  4. From the "Settings" Menu, select "Filament Settings". I made the following changes:
    • This opened a new tab for me
    • In Filament: I set "Color" to my color
    • In Filament: I set "Diameter" to 1.75
    • In Filament: I set "Extrusion Multiplier" to 0.97
    • When done, I clicked the save icon in the top right, next to the drop down.
  5. From the "Settings" Menu, select "Printer Settings". I made the following changes:
    • This opened a new tab for me
    • In General: Verify "Bed Shape" is set to "Circular" and 340 mm Diameter
    • In General: I set "G-code Flavor" to Smoothieware
    • In Extruder 1: Verify "Nozzle Diameter" is set to 0.4 mm
    • In Extruder 1: Verify "Nozzle Diameter" is set to 0.4 mm
    • ** In Extruder 1: I was using but removed, the "Extra length on restart" set to 1. This was part of my attempt to fix my initial bad print... maybe don't do this?
    • In Custom G-code: I added the following:

Start G-code

M280 S10.6 ; Clear BLTouch Errors
G28 ; Home all axis
M280 S3 ; BLTouch Extend Probe
G1 Z50 F25000 ; Move to z=50 very fast
G30 Z1.41 ; Set GLTouch offset to .7 ?? Why?
M280 S7 ; BLTouch Retract Probe
G1 X0 Y0 Z100 ; lift nozzle to z= 100
M42 ; Set stop if out of material (if supported)

End G-code

G92 E0 ; Zero extruder position
G1 E-8.0 F9000 ; Back out fillament to -8mm at high speed
M104 S0 ; turn off temperature
M140 S0 ; turn off bed
G28  ; home  axis
;M84     ; disable motors
  • When done, I clicked the save icon in the top right, next to the drop down.
  • I also exported exported the config bundle via the "File" Menu to make sure I have all my changes for the future.

Initial Version
Load and Print a test object

I am still using PronterFace to test and build objects as the touch interface does provide me with the level of visibility I want into the GCode it sends. (It crashed my hot end into the base plate more than I like). Here is the process that I use.

  • Download and Edit Model as needed
  • Adjust Slic3r settings as needed
    • Use the above
  • Load model into Slic3r
    • From the "File" menu, Select "Open STL/OBJ/AMF/3MF..."
    • Chose your object file (this will not open a gcode file)
    • Your file will display in the "3D" window
    • You can view the build steps in the "Preview" window (select at the bottom)
  • Slice and export model as GCode
    • From the "Plater" menu, select "Export as G-code," and save to a location you know.
  • Plug the printer into the laptop via the USB cable (if you have not already)
  • Copy GCode to internal memory of printer
    • With the printer powered on, the Smoothieware should appear as an external drive on your computer
    • Copy the gcode file to the flash card
    • Alternatively, power off the printer, physically insert the card into your computer, copy the file, put the card back in the printer and turn it back on.
  • Put new layer of "Blue Tape" on the print bed
    • If you get the expensive WIDE role, you can probably just put down a single layer in the middle.
  • Use PronterFace to Print the file (with output)
    • Open PronterFace / PrintRun
    • Connect to your printer (see above)
    • In the command window, type "@play /sd/ -v"
    • The printer will home to the top, then quickly launch itself to the print bed, stopping at the last moment to verify the nozzle height.
    • This assumes you have validated your BLTouch works
    • This assumes you have calibrated the BLTouch/nozzle offset and updated the slicer config/custom code above
  • Obsessively watch the print to see what will go wrong!

Some of my questions now WITH answers!

  • How does nozzle turn on?
    • The above start G-code will turn everything on and set the build height.
  • How far in does the filament need to be loaded?
    • When I load the filament, I feed it in until the extruder clicks. I do this ~15 mm at a time.
    • Send "G29 E0" to set extruder distance to 0
    • Send "G1 E15" to extrude another 15 mm of filament
    • Repeat until the extruder clicks, then put the tension release so as not to grind it.
  • Do I get the filament to start coming out first?
    • The G-code generated by slicer attempts to extrude a little filament before starting the print. When the skirt is being printed, it also starts the extruder.
  • How to load a design
  • How to print a design
  • How does filament unload when done?
    • This is part of the End G-code above and will pull the filament back 8 mm...
    • note, you must feed the filament back in before the next print as the printer does not catch these 8 mm... Maybe fix in start code?
  • Do I need to clean the nozzle?
    • Still not sure about this, I think this is part of both pulling back the filament at the end of a build and pushing through extra filament at the beginning of the build.

Test Print 1: Calibration shape
I printed the calibration shape (attached above as stack.obj). It took about 20 minutes. On my first try, the filament detached after about 10-15 layers so I aborted the build. Abort your build by typing @abort in the command window and hitting send I changed the feed multiplier from 0.90 back to 1 (default) in Slic3r, re-exported the g-code and printed it again. This time it worked fine.

See pictures above of the actual build.

Commands:

  • To start the build
    • @play /sd/stack.gcode -v
  • To stop the build when it was clearly hosed
    • @abort

Ambient @ Start:

  • 32%-Relative Humidity
  • 68.7F-Ambient Temp
  • 30.45-Pressure
  • 10-Dewpoint

NOTE: I did NOT use golden height for this CRAP... I will on a future build.

Test Print 2: Boaty McBoatface
I printed this object. The build took a little more than 1hr. After about ~1/4 inch had built, the build offset by about 2.5 cm (1/8inch) and continued from there. At this point, the existing build was pushing up against the hot end and further destroyed the build quality. The hot end was pushing its way through already printed material, just killing the whole thing. The build looks terrible (no surprise). It also had the same offset issue after another ~1" of height. Other than the offset, things printed well. The 1/4" looks really good. I'll try again tomorrow and update if it works.

See pictures above of the actual build.

Ambient @ Start:

  • 28%-Humidity
  • 66.9F-Ambient Temp
  • 30.45-Pressure
  • 11-Dewpoint.

NOTE: I did NOT use golden height for this CRAP... I will on a future build.

I'm attributing the build issues to a couple of things:

  • Too much filament
    • Fix by slowing extrude rate from 1 to 0.97
    • I also removed the +1mm of feed for a new layer (I added this, so you probably are fine)
  • The head crashing into the print and stalling, slipping the stepper motor (my guess)
    • Maybe fix by having the head go up between layers perhaps?

Test Print 3: Boaty McBoatface... the Revenge
I re-sliced and printed this object successfully (pictures to follow). The build again took a little more than 1hr.

Changes, as noted above: Feed rate at .97, no retract and pre feed between layers, maybe golden rule levels.... can't remember.

PLA 1.75 @ 230C tip temp

Ambient @ Start:

  • 21%-Humidity
  • 63.6F-Ambient Temp
  • 30.52-Pressure
  • 15-Dewpoint.

Onward
I have now printed several items... all at least basically successful. On some, they have directly adhered to the blue tape. On several the smaller layers are "blurry" possibly as a result of temperature being too high. Later I will print a multi temperature calibration test.

comments.text: Just an FYI, that is not how you want to calculate your feed rate for extruder as it is a bad idea to use the extruder multiplier for this, you want to adjust the steps per mm in the config and it is best is to test over 100mm at a time of more. Use the extruder multiplier to adjust the extrusion between different filament types rather than using it to calibrate the extrusion rate.

This model is my own design for an alternative Star Wars Electronic Binocular kit. It is smaller than the normal electronic binocular kit and most of the greebles are static. When constructed, this model is 119.67mm wide, 176.56mm from front to back, and 69mm tall. The front (objective lens) is designed so that you can add a piece of acrylic or glass before glueing it in place. The ocular lens is simply a recessed square cutout so that you can add a backlit screen. The inside is hollow aside from a center support and the front and back end caps screw on so you can add a battery and simply unscrew one end to change out the battery. When I constructed my binos I discovered that there was a fair amount of sanding that was needed to get all the parts to fit together properly. I used Velcro inside to hold the battery in place. I drilled out a hole on the thumb-rest on the underside and added a push button on/off switch to illuminate the ocular lens screen LEDs and the other two LEDs. I added two LEDs One on the front and one on the top knob. Feel free to tinker with the model and come up with your own ideas. NOTE- I did not make lanyard loops on the model; however, I used two small D-ring picture hangers at each screw point on the back plate and added a leather lanyard. Share, print, and tinker as you wish and enjoy.

description.text:
Thanks to rbross for providing the blank. This made the creation of this bin a 5-minute job without the need of taking any measurements on my own. You may want to have a look at his Harbor Freight X-Wing Collection, if you are using the Harbor Freight instead of the Stanley organizer.

This thing follows Lord_Dowrkins idea and adds a storage box the TIE Striker. The following text is mostly copied from him (except of my notes).

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, and have tried many solutions for maximizing space and keeping the models safe. I reviewed most of the similar designs on Thingiverse, but there were none that had everything I wanted. So I started to design my own series, and based on my collection (I own at least one of almost everything, including Epic (note: I don't own any Scum, so don't expect any Scum ships to be added. I do own everything else)).

My design goals:

  • Maximize Space
  • Attractive Presentation
  • Include the pilot cards (note: unline Lord_Dworking I'll never do so)
  • Include the movement dials whenever possible (note: unlike Lord_Dworkin I'll try to always do so)

So, here is my design for the TIE Striker, holding also one dial.

This will fit the Stanley 25 Compartment Organizer (https://amzn.com/B00005QWYF) or the Harbor Freight 20 Compartment version (https://www.harborfreight.com/tool-storage/part-storage/19-bin-portable-parts-storage-case-93928.html).

As I complete and post more of this collection, I will link them here as well. (note: I also include links to Lord_Dwonkins, but not the other direction)

description.text: Split for better printing

print_settings.Notes:: 0.2mm layer height, no supports, minimum perimeters = 1, Extra perimeters if needed = True, Ensure vertical shell thickness = True, Avoid Crossing Perimeters = True, Detect thin walls = True

description.text:
Multi Drawer Components Cabinet

I designed this because I wanted a components cabinet (similar to those made by manufacturers such as Raaco and Akro-Mils) to store small parts (originally to organise all of my resistors to make it easier to find the one I wanted). There wasn't anything on Thingiverse that completely met my needs, so I drew this up

I have deliberately made the walls of the cabinet carcase quite thin (1mm) as I found that some things on Thingiverse appear to be over engineered in this regard. The lip at the top-front of each drawer slot is to prevent the drawer being accidentally pulled completely out (raise each drawer at an angle to insert / remove). I rejected other retention methods - spring-clip, detents etc as they would complicate a simple design and require thicker walls. The cut-outs in the walls reduce the amount of material used and improve the aesthetic, especially with different coloured drawers.

The drawers are made with thin walls (0.5mm) and turn out to be quite flexible and tough. You can set minimum perimeters = 2, if you want more rigid drawers. The corners are radiused to make it easier to remove small parts (I hate it when a 3mm nut gets stuck in the corner and I have to resort to tweezers to get it out.). The drawers have a finger slot instead of any protruding handle - partly to give a clean aesthetic but mostly to avoid having to use any printing supports.

I've Printed the cabinet carcase in PETG and PLA (at 0.35mm layer height) after having massive fails with ABS (shrinkage, warping and stress cracking). Be warned! the largest size (5 x 6) that fits on my print bed takes a looooong time to print!! Approximately 25hrs (I'm still printing it as I post this). I've printed the drawers in PLA and ABS, PETG having failed at the radiused corner.

I haven't put any feet on the cabinet (I use stick on rubber feet) so they can be epoxied together to form larger sizes if desired.

I drew this in SketchUp and have included the files for those who want to customise or change the design. The design is modular - copy however many of each type of drawer that you want, align them (precisely), group them and export to STL. The "Prototype with Hex Perfs.stl" drawings have a pretty hexagonal perforation infill to the openings but were not structurally sound, and were removed from the final design.

22/12/17

Uploaded picture of the the maximum size that will fit on my print-bed - 30 drawers, 6 x 5. Took 26 hours to print the carcase, plus 20 hours for the drawers.

Update 05/01/18

Have included a clip-on carry handle for those of us who need to move our kit from one venue to another. Hook the clip over the lip at the rear of the cabinet and click it down at the front. It appears to be a fairly strong attachment, I haven't had any come off yet. Obviously, it is most suited to those cabinet configurations with 3 or 5 columns.

It is a simple extrusion so should print cleanly on the majority of printers. I have printed it in PLA at 0.2mm and 0.35mm layer heights.

Next job is to make some sort of clip to prevent the drawers moving during transit. The simple designs I have tried have been unsuccessful so far.

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Notes:

Print Settings - Cabinet Carcase - PLA and PETG (I think ABS would need a heated enclosure)

Print Settings - Drawers - PLA, ABS

0.2mm layer height, no supports, minimum perimeters = 1, Extra perimeters if needed = True, Ensure vertical shell thickness = True, Avoid Crossing Perimeters = True, Detect thin walls = True

remixed_from.author: patniemeyer
remixed_from.title: MP Mini Delta 120mm Glass Build Plate Holders

description.text:
These will hold a 120mm glass plate on the bed of your monoprice mini delta quite securely. You also get some nifty shields that prevent debris from falling into the bottom of your printer. This is a remix of 2 good designs on Thingiverse and I think they are better combined than separate. The reason is that this design doesn't allow the clips to spin, which with previous glass clips on Thingiverse could allow the bed to get free mid-print. These are designed to hug the stock clips tightly, so they become a second point of contact and add to rigidity. You'll want to clip the shield end of this part higher up on the rails, and then slide it down, you'll probably have to wiggle it back and forth a bit to get it over the stock clips.

DEFINITELY CHECK: Each time you re-install your glass plate, make SURE you can still hear the tact switches under the bed click if you press your fingers on the three spots where it goes to auto-level. I'm not responsible for any damages caused by the use of this print.

No
